       <tr class="mergedtoprow">
        <th scope="row">
         Founded
        </th>
        <td>
         <ul>
          <li>
           March 13, 1325:
           <br/>
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexico-Tenochtitlan" title="Mexico-Tenochtitlan">
            Mexico-Tenochtitlan
           </a>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2">
            <a href="#cite_note-2">
             [2]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </li>
          <li>
           August 13, 1521:
           <br/>
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico" title="Ciudad de México">
            Ciudad de México
           </a>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3">
            <a href="#cite_note-3">
             [3]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </li>
          <li>
           November 18, 1824:
           <br/>
           Distrito Federal
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4">
            <a href="#cite_note-4">
             [4]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </li>
          <li>
           January 29, 2016:
           <br/>
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico" title="Ciudad de México">
            Ciudad de México
           </a>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guardianname_5-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-guardianname-5">
             [5]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </td>

         <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Mexico" title="Administrative divisions of Mexico">
          Capital
         </a>
        </th>
        <td>
         8,918,653
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedrow">
        <th scope="row">
         • Rank
        </th>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_Mexican_states_by_population" title="List of Mexican states by population">
          2nd
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedrow">
        <th scope="row">
         • Density
        </th>

         <sup>
          2
         </sup>
         (16,000/sq mi)
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedrow">

        </th>

          1st
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedrow">
        <th scope="row">
         •
         <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">
          Urban
         </a>
        </th>
        <td>
         20.4 million
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
          <a href="#cite_note-9">
           [9]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedtoprow">

           </li>

         </div>

       </tr>

         )
        </td>

         <a href="/wiki/Postal_codes_in_Mexico" title="Postal codes in Mexico">
          Postal code

        </td>

       <tr class="mergedtoprow">
        <th scope="row">
         <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">
          HDI
         </a>
        </th>
        <td>
         <img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/>
         0.831
         <span style="color:#090">
          <b>

          </b>

          </a>
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedtoprow">

         GDP
        </th>

         USD 411 billion
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
          <a href="#cite_note-12">
           [12]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedtoprow">
        <th scope="row">
         Website
        </th>
        <td>
         <span class="url">

           Official website
          </a>
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:left; font-size:smaller">
         <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_engfactobox">
          <b>
           <a href="#ref_engfactobox">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         b. Area of Mexico City that includes non-urban areas at the south
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       <b>
        Mexico City
       </b>
       , or the
       <b>
        City of Mexico
       </b>
       (Spanish:
       <i>
        <span lang="es" xml:lang="es">
         Ciudad de México
        </span>
       </i>
       ,
       <small>
        American Spanish:
       </small>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">
         [sjuˈða(ð) ðe ˈmehiko]
        </a>
       </span>
       <small class="nowrap">
        (
        <span class="unicode haudio">
         <span class="fn">
          <span style="white-space:nowrap">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Es-Ciudad_de_Mexico.ogg" title="About this sound">
            <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
           </a>
          </span>
          <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/26/Es-Ciudad_de_Mexico.ogg" title="Es-Ciudad de Mexico.ogg">
           listen
          </a>
         </span>
        </span>
        )
       </small>
       ;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
        <a href="#cite_note-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       abbreviated as
       <b>
        CDMX
       </b>
       ), is the capital and most populous city of
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">
        Mexico
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">
        North America
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
        <a href="#cite_note-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Mexico City is one of the most important financial centers in the
       <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">
        Americas
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is located in the
       <a href="/wiki/Valley_of_Mexico" title="Valley of Mexico">
        Valley of Mexico
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Valle de México
       </i>
       ), a large valley in the high
       <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">
        plateaus
       </a>
       at the center of
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">
        Mexico
       </a>
       , at an altitude of 2,240 metres (7,350 ft). The city consists of sixteen
       <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Mexico_City" title="Municipalities of Mexico City">
        boroughs
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The 2009 estimated population for the city proper was approximately 8.84 million people,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ZMVM_2009_16-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ZMVM_2009-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with a land area of 1,485 square kilometres (573 sq mi).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to the most recent definition agreed upon by the federal and state governments, the
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Mexico_City" title="Greater Mexico City">
        Greater Mexico City
       </a>
       population is 21.3 million people, making it the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_by_population" title="List of metropolitan areas by population">
        largest metropolitan area
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere">
        Western Hemisphere
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_agglomerations_by_population" title="List of agglomerations by population">
        tenth-largest agglomeration
       </a>
       , and the largest
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">
        Spanish-speaking
       </a>
       city in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN2007PopulationDatabase_18-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UN2007PopulationDatabase-18">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Mexico_City" title="Greater Mexico City">
        Greater Mexico City
       </a>
       has a
       <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">
        GDP
       </a>
       of $411 billion in 2011, making
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Mexico_City" title="Greater Mexico City">
        Mexico City urban agglomeration
       </a>
       one of the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP" title="List of cities by GDP">
        largest metropolitan areas in the world
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The city was responsible for generating 15.8% of Mexico's GDP and the metropolitan area accounted for about 22% of total national GDP.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDP_20-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-GDP-20">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As a stand-alone country, in 2013, Mexico City would be the fifth-largest economy in
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">
        Latin America
       </a>
       —five times as large as
       <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">
        Costa Rica
       </a>
       and about the same size as
       <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">
        Peru
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Mexico’s capital is both the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_continuously_inhabited_cities#America,_Middle" title="List of oldest continuously inhabited cities">
        oldest capital city in the Americas
       </a>
       and one of two founded by Native Americans, the other being
       <a href="/wiki/Quito" title="Quito">
        Quito
       </a>
       , Ecuador. The city was originally built on an island of
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Texcoco" title="Lake Texcoco">
        Lake Texcoco
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/Aztec" title="Aztec">
        Aztecs
       </a>
       in 1325 as
       <a href="/wiki/Tenochtitlan" title="Tenochtitlan">
        Tenochtitlan
       </a>
       , which was almost completely destroyed in the 1521
       <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Tenochtitlan" title="Fall of Tenochtitlan">
        siege of Tenochtitlan
       </a>
       , and subsequently redesigned and rebuilt in accordance with the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_architecture#Spanish_Colonial_architecture" title="Spanish architecture">
        Spanish urban standards
       </a>
       . In 1524, the
       <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Mexico" title="Municipalities of Mexico">
        municipality
       </a>
       of Mexico City was established, known as
       <i>
        México Tenochtitlán
       </i>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gobdf_22-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-gobdf-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and as of 1585 it was officially known as
       <i>
        Ciudad de México
       </i>
       (Mexico City).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gobdf_22-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-gobdf-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Mexico City served as the political, administrative and financial center of a major part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">
        Spanish colonial empire
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_23-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UN-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
       After
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">
        independence from Spain
       </a>
       was achieved, the
       <a href="/wiki/Federal_district" title="Federal district">
        federal district
       </a>
       was created in 1824.
      </p>
      <p>
       After years of demanding greater political
       <a href="/wiki/Autonomy" title="Autonomy">
        autonomy
       </a>
       , residents were given the right to directly elect a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Head_of_Government_of_the_Federal_District" title="Head of Government of the Federal District">
        Head of Government
       </a>
       and the representatives of the
       <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">
        unicameral
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_the_Federal_District" title="Legislative Assembly of the Federal District">
        Legislative Assembly
       </a>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/Election" title="Election">
        popular vote
       </a>
       in 1997. Ever since, the left-wing
       <a href="/wiki/Party_of_the_Democratic_Revolution" title="Party of the Democratic Revolution">
        Party of the Democratic Revolution
       </a>
       (PRD) has controlled both of them.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In recent years, the local government has passed a wave of liberal policies, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Abortion_in_Mexico" title="Abortion in Mexico">
        abortion
       </a>
       on request, a limited form of
       <a href="/wiki/Euthanasia_in_Mexico" title="Euthanasia in Mexico">
        euthanasia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/No-fault_divorce" title="No-fault divorce">
        no-fault divorce
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_Mexico_City" title="Same-sex marriage in Mexico City">
        same-sex marriage
       </a>
       . On January 29, 2016, it ceased to be called the
       <i>
        Federal District
       </i>
       (Spanish:
       <i>
        Distrito Federal
       </i>
       or D.F.).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FederalDistrictNowOfficially_25-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-FederalDistrictNowOfficially-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The former "Distrito Federal" is now officially known as "Ciudad de México" (or "CDMX").
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FederalDistrictNowOfficially_25-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-FederalDistrictNowOfficially-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Mexico City is now in transition to become the country's 32nd federal entity, giving it a level of autonomy comparable to that of a state.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FederalDistrictNowOfficially_25-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-FederalDistrictNowOfficially-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Because of a clause in the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">
        Mexican Constitution
       </a>
       , however, as the seat of the powers of the federation, it can never become a state, unless the capital of the country is relocated elsewhere.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN2_26-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-UN2-26">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>
      <div class="toc" id="toc">

          </span>

          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-27">
           <a href="#Public_transportation">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             9.1
            </span>

            </span>
           </a>
           <ul>
