      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">
        Environment
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Environment">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Water_management_in_Greater_Mexico_City" title="Water management in Greater Mexico City">
        Water management in Greater Mexico City
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wikimania15_Dschwen_(15).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3744" data-file-width="5616" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Wikimania15_Dschwen_%2815%29.jpg/220px-Wikimania15_Dschwen_%2815%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Wikimania15_Dschwen_%2815%29.jpg/330px-Wikimania15_Dschwen_%2815%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Wikimania15_Dschwen_%2815%29.jpg/440px-Wikimania15_Dschwen_%2815%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wikimania15_Dschwen_(15).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Xochimilco
         <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Trajineras&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Trajineras (page does not exist)">
          trajineras
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Originally much of the valley laid beneath the waters of
       <a href="/wiki/Lake_Texcoco" title="Lake Texcoco">
        Lake Texcoco
       </a>
       , a system of interconnected salt and freshwater lakes. The
       <a href="/wiki/Aztec" title="Aztec">
        Aztecs
       </a>
       built dikes to separate the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freshwater" title="Freshwater">
        fresh water
       </a>
       used to raise crops in
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Chinampa" title="Chinampa">
         chinampas
        </a>
       </i>
       and to prevent recurrent floods. These dikes were destroyed during the siege of Tenochtitlan, and during colonial times the Spanish regularly drained the lake to prevent floods. Only a small section of the original lake remains, located outside the Federal District, in the municipality of
       <a href="/wiki/San_Salvador_Atenco" title="San Salvador Atenco">
        Atenco
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">
        State of Mexico
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Architects
       <a href="/wiki/Teodoro_Gonz%C3%A1lez_de_Le%C3%B3n" title="Teodoro González de León">
        Teodoro González de León
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Kalach" title="Alberto Kalach">
        Alberto Kalach
       </a>
       along with a group of Mexican urbanists, engineers and biologists have developed the project plan for
       <i>
        Recovering the City of Lakes
       </i>
       . If approved by the government the project will contribute to the supply of water from natural sources to the
       <a href="/wiki/Valley_of_Mexico" title="Valley of Mexico">
        Valley of Mexico
       </a>
       , the creation of new natural spaces, a great improvement in air quality, and greater population establishment planning.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Pollution">
        Pollution
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Pollution">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution_in_Mexico_City" title="Air pollution in Mexico City">
        Air pollution in Mexico City
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AerialViewMexicoCity.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1936" data-file-width="2592" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/AerialViewMexicoCity.jpg/220px-AerialViewMexicoCity.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/AerialViewMexicoCity.jpg/330px-AerialViewMexicoCity.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/AerialViewMexicoCity.jpg/440px-AerialViewMexicoCity.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:AerialViewMexicoCity.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Air pollution over Mexico City
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       By the 1990s Mexico City had become infamous as one of the world's most polluted cities; however, the city has become a model for dramatically lowering pollution levels. By 2014
       <a href="/wiki/Carbon_monoxide" title="Carbon monoxide">
        carbon monoxide
       </a>
       pollution had dropped dramatically, while levels of
       <a href="/wiki/Sulfur_dioxide" title="Sulfur dioxide">
        sulfur dioxide
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen_dioxide" title="Nitrogen dioxide">
        nitrogen dioxide
       </a>
       were nearly three times lower than in 1992. The levels of signature pollutants in Mexico City are similar to those of
       <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">
        Los Angeles
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
        <a href="#cite_note-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Despite the cleanup, the metropolitan area is still the most
       <a href="/wiki/Ozone" title="Ozone">
        ozone
       </a>
       -polluted part of the country, with ozone levels 2.5 times beyond
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WHO" title="WHO">
        WHO
       </a>
       -defined safe limits.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harvard_71-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-harvard-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       To clean up pollution, the federal and local governments implemented numerous plans including the constant monitoring and reporting of environmental conditions, such as ozone and
       <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen_oxide" title="Nitrogen oxide">
        nitrogen oxides
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-clean_72-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-clean-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       When the levels of these two pollutants reached critical levels, contingency actions were implemented which included closing factories, changing school hours, and extending the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Hoy_No_Circula" title="Hoy No Circula">
         A day without a car
        </a>
       </i>
       program to two days of the week.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-clean_72-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-clean-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The government also instituted industrial technology improvements, a strict biannual vehicle emission inspection and the reformulation of gasoline and
       <a href="/wiki/Diesel_fuel" title="Diesel fuel">
        diesel fuels
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-clean_72-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-clean-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The introduction of
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Metrob%C3%BAs" title="Mexico City Metrobús">
        Metrobús
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit" title="Bus rapid transit">
        bus rapid transit
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/EcoBici_(Mexico_City)" title="EcoBici (Mexico City)">
        Ecobici
       </a>
       bike-sharing were among efforts to encourage alternate, greener forms of transportation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harvard_71-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-harvard-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">
        Politics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Politics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <img alt="Ambox current red.svg" data-file-height="290" data-file-width="360" height="34" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ambox_current_red.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ambox_current_red.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ambox_current_red.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red.svg.png 2x" width="42"/>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This section needs to be
          <b>
           updated
          </b>
          .
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.
          </span>
          <small>
           <i>
            (January 2016)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Federal_District">
        Federal District
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Federal District">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Asamblea_Legislativa_del_Distrito_Federal_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Asamblea_Legislativa_del_Distrito_Federal_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg/220px-Asamblea_Legislativa_del_Distrito_Federal_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Asamblea_Legislativa_del_Distrito_Federal_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg/330px-Asamblea_Legislativa_del_Distrito_Federal_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Asamblea_Legislativa_del_Distrito_Federal_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg/440px-Asamblea_Legislativa_del_Distrito_Federal_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Asamblea_Legislativa_del_Distrito_Federal_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Mexico City's Legislative Assembly building
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Acta Constitutiva de la Federación of January 31, 1824, and the Federal Constitution of October 4, 1824,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
        <a href="#cite_note-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       fixed the political and administrative organization of the
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">
        United Mexican States
       </a>
       after the
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence" title="Mexican War of Independence">
        Mexican War of Independence
       </a>
       . In addition, Section XXVIII of Article 50 gave the new Congress the right to choose where the federal government would be located. This location would then be appropriated as federal land, with the federal government acting as the local authority. The two main candidates to become the capital were Mexico City and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quer%C3%A9taro,_Quer%C3%A9taro" title="Querétaro, Querétaro">
        Querétaro
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Due in large part to the persuasion of representative
       <a href="/wiki/Servando_Teresa_de_Mier" title="Servando Teresa de Mier">
        Servando Teresa de Mier
       </a>
       , Mexico City was chosen because it was the center of the country's population and history, even though Querétaro was closer to the center geographically. The choice was official on November 18, 1824, and Congress delineated a surface area of two leagues square (8,800 acres) centered on the
       <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%B3calo" title="Zócalo">
        Zocalo
       </a>
       . This area was then separated from the
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">
        State of Mexico
       </a>
       , forcing that state's government to move from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palace_of_the_Inquisition_(Museum_of_Mexican_Medicine)" title="Palace of the Inquisition (Museum of Mexican Medicine)">
        Palace of the Inquisition (now Museum of Mexican Medicine)
       </a>
       in the city to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Texcoco,_Mexico_State" title="Texcoco, Mexico State">
        Texcoco
       </a>
       . This area did not include the population centers of the towns of
       <a href="/wiki/Coyoac%C3%A1n" title="Coyoacán">
        Coyoacán
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Xochimilco" title="Xochimilco">
        Xochimilco
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/San_Mateo_Mexicaltzingo" title="San Mateo Mexicaltzingo">
        Mexicaltzingo
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Tlalpan" title="Tlalpan">
        Tlalpan
       </a>
       , all of which remained as part of the State of Mexico.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EncMex2003_75-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EncMex2003-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1854 president
       <a href="/wiki/Antonio_L%C3%B3pez_de_Santa_Anna" title="Antonio López de Santa Anna">
        Antonio López de Santa Anna
       </a>
       enlarged the area of the Federal District almost eightfold from the original 220 to 1,700 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (80 to 660 sq mi), annexing the rural and mountainous areas to secure the strategic mountain passes to the south and southwest to protect the city in event of a foreign invasion. (The
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War" title="Mexican–American War">
        Mexican–American War
       </a>
       had just been fought.) The last changes to the limits of the Federal District were made between 1898 and 1902, reducing the area to the current 1,479 km
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       (571 sq mi) by adjusting the southern border with the state of
       <a href="/wiki/Morelos" title="Morelos">
        Morelos
       </a>
       . By that time, the total number of municipalities within the Federal District was twenty-two.
      </p>
      <p>
       While the Federal District was ruled by the federal government through an appointed governor, the municipalities within it were autonomous, and this duality of powers created tension between the municipalities and the federal government for more than a century. In 1903, Porfirio Díaz largely reduced the powers of the municipalities within the Federal District. Eventually, in December 1928, the federal government decided to abolish all the municipalities of the Federal District. In place of the municipalities, the Federal District was divided into one "Central Department" and 13
       <i>
        delegaciones
       </i>
       (boroughs) administered directly by the government of the Federal District. The Central Department was integrated by the former municipalities of Mexico City, Tacuba, Tacubaya and Mixcoac.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 1941, the
       <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Mar%C3%ADa_de_Anaya" title="Pedro María de Anaya">
        General Anaya
       </a>
       borough was merged to the Central Department, which was then renamed "Mexico City" (thus reviving the name, but not the autonomous municipality). From 1941 to 1970, the Federal District comprised twelve
       <i>
        delegaciones
       </i>
       and Mexico City. In 1970, Mexico City was split into four different
       <i>
        delegaciones
       </i>
       :
       <a href="/wiki/Cuauht%C3%A9moc" title="Cuauhtémoc">
        Cuauhtémoc
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Hidalgo_y_Costilla" title="Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla">
        Miguel Hidalgo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Venustiano_Carranza" title="Venustiano Carranza">
        Venustiano Carranza
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Benito_Ju%C3%A1rez" title="Benito Juárez">
        Benito Juárez
       </a>
       , increasing the number of
       <i>
        delegaciones
       </i>
       to 16. Since then, the whole Federal District, whose
       <i>
        delegaciones
       </i>
       had by then almost formed a single urban area, began to be considered
       <i>
        de facto
       </i>
       a synonym of Mexico City.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-df.gob.mx_76-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-df.gob.mx-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The lack of a
       <i>
        de jure
       </i>
       stipulation left a legal vacuum that led to a number of sterile discussions about whether one concept had engulfed the other or if the latter had ceased to exist altogether. In 1993, the situation was solved by an amendment to the 44th article of the
       <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Mexico" title="Constitution of Mexico">
        Constitution of Mexico
       </a>
       ; Mexico City and the Federal District were stated to be the same entity. The amendment was later introduced into the second article of the Statute of Government of the Federal District.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-df.gob.mx_76-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-df.gob.mx-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On January 29, 2016, Mexico City ceased to be called the
       <i>
        Federal District
       </i>
       (Spanish:
       <i>
        Distrito Federal
       </i>
       or D.F.).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FederalDistrictNowOfficially_25-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-FederalDistrictNowOfficially-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The former "Distrito Federal" is now officially known as "Ciudad de México" (or "CDMX").
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FederalDistrictNowOfficially_25-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-FederalDistrictNowOfficially-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Mexico City is now in transition to become the country's 32nd federal entity, giving it a level of autonomy comparable to that of a state.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FederalDistrictNowOfficially_25-5">
        <a href="#cite_note-FederalDistrictNowOfficially-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Because of a clause in the Mexican Constitution, however, as it is the seat of the powers of the federation, it can never become a state, or the capital of the country has to be relocated elsewhere.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN2_26-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-UN2-26">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Political_structure">
        Political structure
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Political structure">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MexCity-palacio.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1061" data-file-width="2126" height="110" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/MexCity-palacio.jpg/220px-MexCity-palacio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/MexCity-palacio.jpg/330px-MexCity-palacio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/MexCity-palacio.jpg/440px-MexCity-palacio.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MexCity-palacio.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Palace_of_Mexico" title="National Palace of Mexico">
          National Palace of Mexico
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Edificio_Tlatelolco_(S.R.E).JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG/220px-Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG/330px-Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG/440px-Edificio_Tlatelolco_%28S.R.E%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Edificio_Tlatelolco_(S.R.E).JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Offices of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_Foreign_Affairs" title="Secretariat of Foreign Affairs">
          Secretariat of Foreign Affairs
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Mexico City, being the seat of the powers of the Union, belongs not to any particular state but to all of them. Therefore, the president, representing the federation, used to designate the head of government of the Federal District, sometimes called outside Mexico as the "Mayor" of Mexico City.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2008)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       In the 1980s, the dramatic increase in population of the previous decades, the inherent political inconsistencies of the system, and dissatisfaction with the inadequate response of the federal government after the 1985 earthquake made residents begin to request political and administrative autonomy to manage their local affairs.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2008)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       Some
       <a href="/wiki/Political_party" title="Political party">
        political groups
       </a>
       even proposed that the Federal District be converted into the 32nd state of the federation.
      </p>
      <p>
       In response to the demands, the Federal District received a greater degree of autonomy, with the 1987 elaboration the first Statute of Government (
       <i>
        Estatuto de Gobierno
       </i>
       ) and the creation of an Assembly of Representatives.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2008)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       In the 1990s, this autonomy was further expanded and since 1997, residents can directly elect the head of government of the Federal District and the representatives of a unicameral Legislative Assembly, which succeeded the previous assembly, by popular vote.
      </p>
      <p>
       The first elected head of government was
       <a href="/wiki/Cuauht%C3%A9moc_C%C3%A1rdenas" title="Cuauhtémoc Cárdenas">
        Cuauhtémoc Cárdenas
       </a>
       . He resigned in 1999 to run in the 2000
       <a href="/wiki/Election" title="Election">
        presidential elections
       </a>
       and designated
       <a href="/wiki/Rosario_Robles" title="Rosario Robles">
        Rosario Robles
       </a>
       to succeed him, who became the first woman, elected or otherwise, to govern Mexico City. In 2000,
       <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador" title="Andrés Manuel López Obrador">
        Andrés Manuel López Obrador
       </a>
       was elected, and he resigned in 2005 to run in the 2006 presidential elections;
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alejandro_Encinas" title="Alejandro Encinas">
        Alejandro Encinas
       </a>
       was designated by the Legislative Assembly to finish the term. In 2006,
       <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_Ebrard" title="Marcelo Ebrard">
        Marcelo Ebrard
       </a>
       was elected to serve until 2012.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Federal District does not have a constitution, unlike the states of the Union, but it has a Statute of Government. As part of the recent changes in autonomy, the budget is administered locally; it is proposed by the head of government and approved by the Legislative Assembly. Nonetheless, it is the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Congress_of_Mexico" title="Congress of Mexico">
        Congress of the Union
       </a>
       that sets the ceiling to internal and external
       <a href="/wiki/Government_debt" title="Government debt">
        public debt
       </a>
       issued by the Federal District.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
        <a href="#cite_note-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the 44th article of the Mexican Constitution, if the powers of the Union move to another city, the Federal District would become a new state, the "State of the Valley of Mexico", with the new limits set by the Congress of the Union.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb noresize tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; overflow:hidden; width:auto; max-width:1008px;">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="">
        <div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Federal_District_buildings_on_Zocalo_Mexico_City.jpg" title="Government offices in the Zócalo">
          <img alt="Government offices in the Zócalo" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="5000" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Federal_District_buildings_on_Zocalo_Mexico_City.jpg/1000px-Federal_District_buildings_on_Zocalo_Mexico_City.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Federal_District_buildings_on_Zocalo_Mexico_City.jpg/1500px-Federal_District_buildings_on_Zocalo_Mexico_City.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Federal_District_buildings_on_Zocalo_Mexico_City.jpg/2000px-Federal_District_buildings_on_Zocalo_Mexico_City.jpg 2x" width="1000"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Federal_District_buildings_on_Zocalo_Mexico_City.jpg" title="File:Federal District buildings on Zocalo Mexico City.jpg">
          </a>
         </div>
         Government offices in the Zócalo
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Elections_and_government">
        Elections and government
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Elections and government">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Mancera_recibiendo_su_constancia_de_Jefe_de_Gobierno_electo.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1263" data-file-width="528" height="526" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Mancera_recibiendo_su_constancia_de_Jefe_de_Gobierno_electo.jpg/220px-Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Mancera_recibiendo_su_constancia_de_Jefe_de_Gobierno_electo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Mancera_recibiendo_su_constancia_de_Jefe_de_Gobierno_electo.jpg/330px-Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Mancera_recibiendo_su_constancia_de_Jefe_de_Gobierno_electo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Mancera_recibiendo_su_constancia_de_Jefe_de_Gobierno_electo.jpg/440px-Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Mancera_recibiendo_su_constancia_de_Jefe_de_Gobierno_electo.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Mancera_recibiendo_su_constancia_de_Jefe_de_Gobierno_electo.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Mexico City's
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Head_of_Government_of_the_Federal_District" title="Head of Government of the Federal District">
          Head of Government
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Miguel_%C3%81ngel_Mancera" title="Miguel Ángel Mancera">
          Miguel Ángel Mancera
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 2012, elections were held for the post of head of government and the representatives of the Legislative Assembly. Heads of government are elected for a six-year period without the possibility of re-election. Traditionally, the position has been considered as the second most important executive office in the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_the_Federal_District" title="Legislative Assembly of the Federal District">
        Legislative Assembly of the Federal District
       </a>
       is formed, as it is the case for state legislatures in Mexico, by both single-seat and proportional seats, making it a system of
       <a href="/wiki/Parallel_voting" title="Parallel voting">
        parallel voting
       </a>
       . The Federal District is divided into 40 electoral constituencies of similar population which elect one representative by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" title="Plurality voting system">
        plurality voting system
       </a>
       , locally called "uninominal deputies". The Federal District, as a whole, is a single constituency for the parallel election of 26 representatives, elected by
       <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">
        proportional representation
       </a>
       , with open-party lists, locally called "plurinominal deputies".
      </p>
      <p>
       Even though
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proportionality_(political_maxim)" title="Proportionality (political maxim)">
        proportionality
       </a>
       is supposed to prevent a party from being overrepresented, several restrictions apply in the assignation of the seats. No party can have more than 63% of all seats, both uninominal and plurinominal. In the 2006 elections, the PRD got the absolute majority in the direct uninominal elections, securing 34 of the 40 FPP seats. As such, the PRD was not assigned any plurinominal seat to comply with the law that prevents over-representation. The overall composition of the Legislative Assembly is:
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <tr>

      <p>
       The politics pursued by the administrations of heads of government in Mexico City since the second half of the 20th century have usually been more liberal than those of the rest of the country, whether with the support of the federal government, as was the case with the approval of several comprehensive environmental laws in the 1980s, or by laws that were since approved by the Legislative Assembly. The Legislative Assembly expanded provisions on abortions, becoming the first federal entity to expand
       <a href="/wiki/Abortion_in_Mexico" title="Abortion in Mexico">
        abortion in Mexico
       </a>
       beyond cases of rape and economic reasons, to permit it at the choice of the mother before the 12th week of pregnancy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In December 2009, the Federal District became the first city in Latin America and one of very few in the world to legalize
       <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">
        same-sex marriage
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Boroughs_and_neighborhoods">
        Boroughs and neighborhoods
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Boroughs and neighborhoods">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexico_City%27s_boroughs" title="Mexico City's boroughs">
        Mexico City's boroughs
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_neighborhoods_in_Mexico_City" title="List of neighborhoods in Mexico City">
        Neighborhoods in Mexico City
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Boroughs_of_Mexican_Federal_District_numbered.svg">

        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bavarian_house_in_Mexico_City.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A German-style home, now a restaurant, in the San Angel neighborhood
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       For administrative purposes, the Federal District is divided into 16 "delegaciones", or boroughs. While they are not fully equivalent to municipalities, the boroughs have gained significant autonomy, and since 2000, their heads of government have been elected directly by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" title="Plurality voting system">
        plurality
       </a>
       (they had been appointed by the head of government of the Federal District). Since Mexico City is organized entirely as a Federal District, most of the
       <a href="/wiki/Municipal_services" title="Municipal services">
        city services
       </a>
       are provided or organized by the Government of the Federal District, not by the boroughs themselves; in the
       <a href="/wiki/Constituent_state" title="Constituent state">
        constituent states
       </a>
       , such services would be provided by the municipalities. The boroughs of the Federal District with their 2010 populations are:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table cellspacing="8">
       <tr>
        <td style="width:50%;">
         <p>
          1.
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Obreg%C3%B3n,_D.F." title="Álvaro Obregón, D.F.">
           Álvaro Obregón
          </a>
          (pop. 727,034)
          <br/>
          2.
          <a href="/wiki/Azcapotzalco" title="Azcapotzalco">
           Azcapotzalco
          </a>
          (pop. 414,711)
          <br/>
          3.
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benito_Ju%C3%A1rez,_D.F." title="Benito Juárez, D.F.">
           Benito Juárez
          </a>
          (pop. 385,439)
          <br/>
          4.
          <a href="/wiki/Coyoac%C3%A1n" title="Coyoacán">
           Coyoacán
          </a>
          (pop. 620,416)
          <br/>
          5.
          <a href="/wiki/Cuajimalpa" title="Cuajimalpa">
           Cuajimalpa
          </a>
          (pop. 186,391)
          <br/>
          6.
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuauht%C3%A9moc,_D.F." title="Cuauhtémoc, D.F.">
           Cuauhtémoc
          </a>
          (pop. 531,831)
          <br/>
          7.
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gustavo_A._Madero,_D.F." title="Gustavo A. Madero, D.F.">
           Gustavo A. Madero
          </a>
          (pop. 1,185,772)
          <br/>
          8.
          <a href="/wiki/Iztacalco" title="Iztacalco">
           Iztacalco
          </a>
          (pop. 384,326)
         </p>
        </td>
        <td style="width:33%;">
         <p>
          9.
          <a href="/wiki/Iztapalapa" title="Iztapalapa">
           Iztapalapa
          </a>
          (pop. 1,815,786)
          <br/>
          10.
          <a href="/wiki/Magdalena_Contreras" title="Magdalena Contreras">
           Magdalena Contreras
          </a>
          (pop. 239,086)
          <br/>
          11.
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miguel_Hidalgo,_D.F." title="Miguel Hidalgo, D.F.">
           Miguel Hidalgo
          </a>
          (pop. 372,889)
          <br/>
          12.
          <a href="/wiki/Milpa_Alta" title="Milpa Alta">
           Milpa Alta
          </a>
          (pop. 130,582)
          <br/>
          13.
          <a href="/wiki/Tl%C3%A1huac" title="Tláhuac">
           Tláhuac
          </a>
          (pop. 360,265)
          <br/>
          14.
          <a href="/wiki/Tlalpan" title="Tlalpan">
           Tlalpan
          </a>
          (pop. 650,567)
          <br/>
          15.
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Venustiano_Carranza,_D.F." title="Venustiano Carranza, D.F.">
           Venustiano Carranza
          </a>
          (pop. 430,978)
          <br/>
          16.
          <a href="/wiki/Xochimilco" title="Xochimilco">
           Xochimilco
          </a>
          (pop. 415,007)
         </p>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The boroughs are composed by hundreds of
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colonias_of_Mexico_City" title="Colonias of Mexico City">
         colonias
        </a>
       </i>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Neighbourhood" title="Neighbourhood">
        neighborhoods
       </a>
       , which have no jurisdictional autonomy or representation. The
       <a href="/wiki/Historic_center_of_Mexico_City" title="Historic center of Mexico City">
        Historic Center
       </a>
       is the oldest part of the city (along with some other, formerly separate colonial towns such as
       <a href="/wiki/Coyoac%C3%A1n" title="Coyoacán">
        Coyoacán
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/San_%C3%81ngel" title="San Ángel">
        San Ángel
       </a>
       ), some of the buildings
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_structures_in_Mexico_City" title="List of oldest structures in Mexico City">
        dating back to the 16th century
       </a>
       . Other well-known central neighborhoods include
       <a href="/wiki/Condesa" title="Condesa">
        Condesa
       </a>
       , known for its
       <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">
        Art Deco
       </a>
       architecture and its restaurant scene;
       <a href="/wiki/Colonia_Roma" title="Colonia Roma">
        Colonia Roma
       </a>
       , a
       <a href="/wiki/Beaux-Arts_architecture" title="Beaux-Arts architecture">
        beaux arts
       </a>
       neighborhood and artistic and culinary hot-spot, the
       <a href="/wiki/Zona_Rosa,_Mexico_City" title="Zona Rosa, Mexico City">
        Zona Rosa
       </a>
       , formerly the center of nightlife and restaurants, now reborn as the center of the
       <a href="/wiki/LGBT_in_Mexico" title="LGBT in Mexico">
        LGBT
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Koreans_in_Mexico" title="Koreans in Mexico">
        Korean-Mexican
       </a>
       communities; and
       <a href="/wiki/Tepito" title="Tepito">
        Tepito
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_Lagunilla" title="La Lagunilla">
        La Lagunilla
       </a>
       , known for their local working-class foklore and large
       <a href="/wiki/Flea_market" title="Flea market">
        flea markets
       </a>
       .
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santa_Mar%C3%ADa_la_Ribera" title="Santa María la Ribera">
        Santa María la Ribera
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Colonia_San_Rafael" title="Colonia San Rafael">
        San Rafael
       </a>
       are the latest neighborhoods of magnificent
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Porfiriato" title="Porfiriato">
        Porfiriato
       </a>
       architecture seeing the first signs of gentrification.
      </p>
      <p>
       West of the
       <a href="/wiki/Historic_center_of_Mexico_City" title="Historic center of Mexico City">
        Historic Center
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Centro Histórico
       </i>
       ) along
       <a href="/wiki/Paseo_de_la_Reforma" title="Paseo de la Reforma">
        Paseo de la Reforma
       </a>
       are many of the city's wealthiest neighborhoods such as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polanco" title="Polanco">
        Polanco
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lomas_de_Chapultepec" title="Lomas de Chapultepec">
        Lomas de Chapultepec
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bosques_de_las_Lomas" title="Bosques de las Lomas">
        Bosques de las Lomas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Santa_Fe,_Mexico_City" title="Santa Fe, Mexico City">
        Santa Fe
       </a>
       , and (in the State of Mexico)
       <a href="/wiki/Interlomas" title="Interlomas">
        Interlomas
       </a>
       , which are also the city's most important areas of class A office space, corporate headquarters, skyscrapers and shopping malls. Nevertheless, some areas of lower-income
       <i>
        colonias
       </i>
       are right next to rich neighborhoods, particularly in the case of Santa Fe.
      </p>
      <p>
       The south of the city is home to some other high-income neighborhoods such as
       <a href="/wiki/Colonia_del_Valle" title="Colonia del Valle">
        Colonia del Valle
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Jardines_del_Pedregal" title="Jardines del Pedregal">
        Jardines del Pedregal
       </a>
       and the formerly separate colonial towns of
       <a href="/wiki/Coyoac%C3%A1n" title="Coyoacán">
        Coyoacán
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/San_%C3%81ngel" title="San Ángel">
        San Ángel
       </a>
       , and San Jerónimo. Along
       <a href="/wiki/Avenida_de_los_Insurgentes" title="Avenida de los Insurgentes">
        Avenida Insurgentes
       </a>
       from
       <a href="/wiki/Paseo_de_la_Reforma" title="Paseo de la Reforma">
        Paseo de la Reforma
       </a>
       , near the center, south past the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_Mexico_City" title="World Trade Center Mexico City">
        World Trade Center
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNAM" title="UNAM">
        UNAM
       </a>
       university towards the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Perif%C3%A9rico" title="Periférico">
        Periférico
       </a>
       ring road, is another important corridor of corporate office space. The far-southern boroughs of
       <a href="/wiki/Xochimilco" title="Xochimilco">
        Xochimilco
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Tl%C3%A1huac" title="Tláhuac">
        Tláhuac
       </a>
       have a significant rural population, with
       <a href="/wiki/Milpa_Alta" title="Milpa Alta">
        Milpa Alta
       </a>
       being entirely rural.
      </p>
      <p>
       East of the center are mostly lower-income areas with some middle-class neighborhoods such as Jardín Balbuena. Urban sprawl continues further east for many miles into the State of Mexico, including
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ciudad_Nezahualcoyotl" title="Ciudad Nezahualcoyotl">
        Ciudad Nezahualcoyotl
       </a>
       , now increasingly middle-class, but once full of informal settlements. Such slums are still found on the eastern edges of the metropolitan area in the
       <a href="/wiki/Valle_de_Chalco" title="Valle de Chalco">
        Chalco
       </a>
       area.
      </p>
      <p>
       North of the Historic Center,
       <a href="/wiki/Azcapotzalco" title="Azcapotzalco">
        Azcapotzalco
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gustavo_A._Madero,_D.F." title="Gustavo A. Madero, D.F.">
        Gustavo A. Madero
       </a>
       have important industrial centers and neighborhoods that range from established middle-class
       <i>
        colonias
       </i>
       such as Claveria and
       <a href="/wiki/Lindavista" title="Lindavista">
        Lindavista
       </a>
       to huge low-income housing areas that share hillsides with adjacent municipalities in the
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">
        State of Mexico
       </a>
       . In recent years, much of northern Mexico City's industry has moved to nearby municipalities in the
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">
        State of Mexico
       </a>
       . Northwest of Mexico City itself is
       <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Sat%C3%A9lite" title="Ciudad Satélite">
        Ciudad Satélite
       </a>
       , a vast middle to upper-middle-class residential and business area.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">
        Human Development Index
       </a>
       report of 2005
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DISTRITO_FEDERAL_81-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-DISTRITO_FEDERAL-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       shows that there were three boroughs with a very high Human Development Index, 12 with a high HDI value (9 above .85) and one with a medium HDI value (almost high).
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benito_Juarez,_D.F." title="Benito Juarez, D.F.">
        Benito Juárez
       </a>
       borough had the highest HDI of the country (0.9510) followed by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miguel_Hidalgo,_D.F." title="Miguel Hidalgo, D.F.">
        Miguel Hidalgo
       </a>
       which came up fourth nationally with a HDI of (0.9189) and
       <a href="/wiki/Coyoac%C3%A1n" title="Coyoacán">
        Coyoacán
       </a>
       was fifth nationally, with a HDI of (0.9169).
       <a href="/wiki/Cuajimalpa" title="Cuajimalpa">
        Cuajimalpa
       </a>
       (15th),
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Cuauht%C3%A9moc_(23rd),_D.F.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Cuauhtémoc (23rd), D.F. (page does not exist)">
        Cuauhtémoc
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Azcapotzalco" title="Azcapotzalco">
        Azcapotzalco
       </a>
       (25th) also had very high values of respectively 0.8994, 0.8922, and 0.8915.
      </p>
      <p>
       In contrast, the boroughs of
       <a href="/wiki/Xochimilco" title="Xochimilco">
        Xochimilco
       </a>
       (172nd),
       <a href="/wiki/Tl%C3%A1huac" title="Tláhuac">
        Tláhuac
       </a>
       (177th), and
       <a href="/wiki/Iztapalapa" title="Iztapalapa">
        Iztapalapa
       </a>
       (183rd) presented the lowest HDI values of the Federal District with values of 0.8481, 0.8473, and 0.8464 respectively, which are still in the global high-HDI range. The only borough that did not have a high HDI was that of rural
       <a href="/wiki/Milpa_Alta" title="Milpa Alta">
        Milpa Alta
       </a>
       , which had a "medium" HDI of 0.7984, far below all of the other boroughs (627th nationally, the rest being in the top 200). Mexico City's HDI for the 2005 report was of 0.9012 (very high), and its 2010 value of 0.9225 (very high), or (by newer methodology) 0.8307, was Mexico's highest.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Metropolitan_area">
        Metropolitan area
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Metropolitan area">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Mexico_City" title="Greater Mexico City">
        Greater Mexico City
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MX-DF-Crecimiento_de_la_ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1056" data-file-width="816" height="285" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/MX-DF-Crecimiento_de_la_ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.png/220px-MX-DF-Crecimiento_de_la_ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/MX-DF-Crecimiento_de_la_ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.png/330px-MX-DF-Crecimiento_de_la_ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/MX-DF-Crecimiento_de_la_ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.png/440px-MX-DF-Crecimiento_de_la_ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MX-DF-Crecimiento_de_la_ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Growth of Mexico city's area from 1900 to 2000
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Greater Mexico City is formed by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_District" title="Federal District">
        Federal District
       </a>
       , 60 municipalities from the
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">
        State of Mexico
       </a>
       and one from the state of
       <a href="/wiki/Hidalgo_(state)" title="Hidalgo (state)">
        Hidalgo
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Mexico_City" title="Greater Mexico City">
        Greater Mexico City
       </a>
       is the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_of_Mexico" title="List of metropolitan areas of Mexico">
        largest metropolitan area in Mexico
       </a>
       and the area with the highest population density. As of 2009
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , 21,163,226 people live in this urban agglomeration, of which 8,841,916 live in Mexico City proper.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ZMVM_2009_16-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ZMVM_2009-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In terms of population, the biggest municipalities that are part of Greater Mexico City (excluding Mexico City proper) are:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atizapan_de_Zaragoza" title="Atizapan de Zaragoza">
         Atizapan de Zaragoza
        </a>
        (
        <abbr title="population">
         pop.
        </abbr>
        489,775)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Chimalhuac%C3%A1n" title="Chimalhuacán">
         Chimalhuacán
        </a>
        (pop. 602,079)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Cuautitl%C3%A1n_Izcalli" title="Cuautitlán Izcalli">
         Cuautitlán Izcalli
        </a>
        (pop. 532,973)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Ecatepec_de_Morelos" title="Ecatepec de Morelos">
         Ecatepec de Morelos
        </a>
        (pop. 1,658,806)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Ixtapaluca" title="Ixtapaluca">
         Ixtapaluca
        </a>
        (pop. 467,630)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Naucalpan" title="Naucalpan">
         Naucalpan
        </a>
        (pop. 833,782)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Nezahualc%C3%B3yotl" title="Ciudad Nezahualcóyotl">
         Nezahualcóyotl
        </a>
        (pop. 1,109,363)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Tlalnepantla_de_Baz" title="Tlalnepantla de Baz">
         Tlalnepantla de Baz
        </a>
        (pop. 664,160)
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       The above municipalities are located in the state of Mexico but are part of the Greater Mexico City area. Approximately 75% (10 million) of the state of México's population live in municipalities that are part of Greater Mexico City's conurbation.
      </p>
      <p>
       Greater Mexico City was the fastest growing metropolitan area in the country until the late 1980s. Since then, and through a policy of decentralization in order to reduce the environmental pollutants of the growing conurbation, the annual rate of growth of the agglomeration has decreased, and it is lower than that of the other four largest metropolitan areas (namely
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Guadalajara" title="Greater Guadalajara">
        Greater Guadalajara
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Monterrey" title="Greater Monterrey">
        Greater Monterrey
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Puebla" title="Greater Puebla">
        Greater Puebla
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Toluca" title="Greater Toluca">
        Greater Toluca
       </a>
       ) even though it is still positive.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sintesis_83-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-sintesis-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Net_migration_rate" title="Net migration rate">
        net migration rate
       </a>
       of Mexico City proper from 1995 to 2000 was negative,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which implies that residents are moving to the suburbs of the metropolitan area, or to other states of Mexico. In addition, some inner suburbs are losing population to outer suburbs, indicating the continuing expansion of Greater Mexico City.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Health">
        Health
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Health">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud,_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.,_M%C3%A9xico,_2014-10-13,_DD_12.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2932" data-file-width="5047" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2014-10-13%2C_DD_12.JPG/220px-Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2014-10-13%2C_DD_12.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2014-10-13%2C_DD_12.JPG/330px-Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2014-10-13%2C_DD_12.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2014-10-13%2C_DD_12.JPG/440px-Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud%2C_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.%2C_M%C3%A9xico%2C_2014-10-13%2C_DD_12.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Secretar%C3%ADa_de_Salud,_M%C3%A9xico_D.F.,_M%C3%A9xico,_2014-10-13,_DD_12.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_Health_(Mexico)" title="Secretariat of Health (Mexico)">
          Secretariat of Health building
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Mexico City is home to some of the best private hospitals in the country; Hospital Ángeles, Hospital ABC and Médica Sur to name a few. The national
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Publicly-funded_health_care" title="Publicly-funded health care">
        public healthcare
       </a>
       institution for
       <a href="/wiki/Private_sector" title="Private sector">
        private-sector
       </a>
       employees,
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Social_Security_Institute" title="Mexican Social Security Institute">
        IMSS
       </a>
       , has its largest facilities in Mexico City—including the National Medical Center and the
       <a href="/wiki/La_Raza" title="La Raza">
        La Raza
       </a>
       Medical Center—and has an annual budget of over 6 billion pesos. The IMSS and other
       <a href="/wiki/Public_health" title="Public health">
        public health
       </a>
       institutions, including the ISSSTE (Public Sector Employees' Social Security Institute) and the National Health Ministry (SSA) maintain large specialty facilities in the city. These include the National Institutes of Cardiology, Nutrition, Psychiatry, Oncology, Pediatrics, Rehabilitation, among others.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">
        World Bank
       </a>
       has sponsored a project to curb air pollution through public transport improvements and the Mexican government has started shutting down polluting factories. They have phased out diesel buses and mandated new emission controls on new cars; since 1993 all new cars must be fitted with a
       <a href="/wiki/Catalytic_converter" title="Catalytic converter">
        catalytic converter
       </a>
       , which reduces the emissions released. Trucks must use only
       <a href="/wiki/Liquefied_petroleum_gas" title="Liquefied petroleum gas">
        liquefied petroleum gas
       </a>
       (LPG). Also construction of an
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Metro" title="Mexico City Metro">
        underground rail system
       </a>
       was begun in 1968 in order to help curb air pollution problems and alleviate
       <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">
        traffic congestion
       </a>
       . Today it has over 201 km (125 mi) of track and carries over 5 million people every day. Fees are kept low to encourage use of the system and during
       <a href="/wiki/Rush_hour" title="Rush hour">
        rush hours
       </a>
       the crush is so great, that authorities have reserved a special carriage specifically for women. Due to these initiatives and others, the air quality in Mexico City has begun to improve, with the air becoming cleaner since 1991, when the air quality was declared to be a public health risk for 355 days of the year.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2012)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Economy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bolsa_Mexicana_de_Valores.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2632" data-file-width="2216" height="261" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Bolsa_Mexicana_de_Valores.png/220px-Bolsa_Mexicana_de_Valores.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Bolsa_Mexicana_de_Valores.png/330px-Bolsa_Mexicana_de_Valores.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Bolsa_Mexicana_de_Valores.png/440px-Bolsa_Mexicana_de_Valores.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bolsa_Mexicana_de_Valores.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Stock_Exchange" title="Mexican Stock Exchange">
          Mexican Stock Exchange
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Paseo_de_la_Reforma" title="Paseo de la Reforma">
          Paseo de la Reforma
         </a>
         , Mexico City
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Mexico City is one of the most important economic hubs in
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">
        Latin America
       </a>
       . The city proper produces 15.8% of the country's
       <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">
        gross domestic product
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INEGI_85-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-INEGI-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to a study conducted by
       <a href="/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers" title="PricewaterhouseCoopers">
        PwC
       </a>
       , Mexico City had a GDP of $390 billion, ranking it as the eighth richest city in the world and the richest in Latin America.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ukmediacentre.pwc.com_86-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ukmediacentre.pwc.com-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Mexico City alone would rank as the 30th largest economy in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-emporis_87-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-emporis-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Mexico City is the greatest contributor to the country's industrial GDP (15.8%) and also the greatest contributor to the country's GDP in the
       <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">
        service sector
       </a>
       (25.3%). Due to the limited non-urbanized space at the south—most of which is protected through environmental laws—the contribution of the Federal District in agriculture is the smallest of all federal entities in the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INEGI_85-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-INEGI-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Mexico City has one of the world's fastest-growing economies and its GDP is set to double by 2020.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-furness_88-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-furness-88">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2002, Mexico City had a
       <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">
        Human Development Index
       </a>
       score of 0.915,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       identical to that of
       <a href="/wiki/International_rankings_of_South_Korea" title="International rankings of South Korea">
        South Korea
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The top twelve percent of GDP per capita holders in the city had a mean
       <a href="/wiki/Disposable_and_discretionary_income" title="Disposable and discretionary income">
        disposable income
       </a>
       of
       <span style="white-space: nowrap">
        <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">
         US$
        </a>
        98,517
       </span>
       in 2007. The high spending power of Mexico City inhabitants makes the city attractive for companies offering prestige and
       <a href="/wiki/Luxury_goods" title="Luxury goods">
        luxury goods
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The economic reforms of President
       <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Salinas_de_Gortari" title="Carlos Salinas de Gortari">
        Carlos Salinas de Gortari
       </a>
       had a tremendous effect on the city, as a number of businesses, including banks and airlines, were privatized. He also signed the
       <a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">
        North American Free Trade Agreement
       </a>
       (NAFTA). This led to decentralization
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-furness_88-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-furness-88">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and a shift in Mexico City's economic base, from manufacturing to services, as most factories moved away to either the
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">
        State of Mexico
       </a>
       , or more commonly to the northern border. By contrast, corporate office buildings set their base in the city.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Demographics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Basilica_de_Guadalupe,_tambien_llamada_La_Villa..JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Basilica_de_Guadalupe%2C_tambien_llamada_La_Villa..JPG/220px-Basilica_de_Guadalupe%2C_tambien_llamada_La_Villa..JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Basilica_de_Guadalupe%2C_tambien_llamada_La_Villa..JPG/330px-Basilica_de_Guadalupe%2C_tambien_llamada_La_Villa..JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Basilica_de_Guadalupe%2C_tambien_llamada_La_Villa..JPG/440px-Basilica_de_Guadalupe%2C_tambien_llamada_La_Villa..JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Basilica_de_Guadalupe,_tambien_llamada_La_Villa..JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         La Villa de Guadalupe, the main Catholic pilgrimage site in Mexico
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sinagoga_Historica.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="768" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Sinagoga_Historica.jpg/220px-Sinagoga_Historica.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Sinagoga_Historica.jpg/330px-Sinagoga_Historica.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Sinagoga_Historica.jpg/440px-Sinagoga_Historica.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sinagoga_Historica.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A Synagogue in Downtown Mexico City
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ChineseArchMexicoCity.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/ChineseArchMexicoCity.JPG/220px-ChineseArchMexicoCity.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/ChineseArchMexicoCity.JPG/330px-ChineseArchMexicoCity.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/ChineseArchMexicoCity.JPG/440px-ChineseArchMexicoCity.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ChineseArchMexicoCity.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Paifang" title="Paifang">
          Paifang
         </a>
         in the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Mexico_City" title="Chinatown, Mexico City">
          Barrio Chino
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Historically, and since
       <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_era" title="Pre-Columbian era">
        Pre-Columbian
       </a>
       times, the
       <a href="/wiki/Valley_of_Mexico" title="Valley of Mexico">
        Valley of Anahuac
       </a>
       has been one of the most densely populated areas in Mexico. When the Federal District was created in 1824, the urban area of Mexico City extended approximately to the area of today's
       <a href="/wiki/Cuauht%C3%A9moc" title="Cuauhtémoc">
        Cuauhtémoc
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Borough" title="Borough">
        borough
       </a>
       . At the beginning of the 20th century, the
       <i>
        elites
       </i>
       began migrating to the south and west and soon the small towns of
       <a href="/wiki/Mixcoac" title="Mixcoac">
        Mixcoac
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/San_%C3%81ngel" title="San Ángel">
        San Ángel
       </a>
       were incorporated by the growing conurbation. According to the 1921 census, 54.78% of the city's population was considered Mestizo (Indigenous mixed with European), 30.79% considered European, and 10.74% considered Indigenous.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
        <a href="#cite_note-90">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This was the last Mexican Census which asked people to self-identify with an heritage other than Amerindian. However, the census had the particularity that, unlike racial/ethnic census in other countries, it was focused in the perception of
       <a href="/wiki/Cultural_heritage" title="Cultural heritage">
        cultural heritage
       </a>
       rather than in a racial perception, leading to a good number of white people to identify with "Mixed heritage" due cultural influence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
        <a href="#cite_note-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1921, Mexico City had less than one million inhabitants.
      </p>
      <p>
       Up to the 1990s, the Federal District was the most populous
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_divisions_of_Mexico" title="Political divisions of Mexico">
        federal entity
       </a>
       in Mexico, but since then its population has remained stable at around 8.7 million. The growth of the city has extended beyond the limits of the Federal District to 59 municipalities of the
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">
        state of Mexico
       </a>
       and 1 in the state of
       <a href="/wiki/Hidalgo_(state)" title="Hidalgo (state)">
        Hidalgo
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CONAPOzm2005_92-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CONAPOzm2005-92">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       With a population of approximately 19.8 million inhabitants (2008),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CONAPOProy2_93-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CONAPOProy2-93">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       it is one of the most populous conurbations in the world. Nonetheless, the annual rate of growth of the
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Mexico_City" title="Greater Mexico City">
        Metropolitan Area of Mexico City
       </a>
       is much lower than that of other large urban agglomerations in Mexico,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sintesis_83-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-sintesis-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       a phenomenon most likely attributable to the
       <a href="/wiki/Environmental_policy" title="Environmental policy">
        environmental policy
       </a>
       of decentralization. The
       <a href="/wiki/Net_migration_rate" title="Net migration rate">
        net migration rate
       </a>
       of the Federal District from 1995 to 2000 was negative.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
        <a href="#cite_note-94">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Representing around 10.74% of the city's population,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Mexico" title="Indigenous peoples in Mexico">
        indigenous peoples
       </a>
       from different areas of Mexico have migrated to the capital in search of better economic opportunities.
       <a href="/wiki/Nahuatl" title="Nahuatl">
        Nahuatl
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Otomi_language" title="Otomi language">
        Otomi
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mixtec" title="Mixtec">
        Mixtec
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Zapotec_languages" title="Zapotec languages">
        Zapotec
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Mazahua_language" title="Mazahua language">
        Mazahua
       </a>
       are the indigenous languages with the greatest number of speakers in Mexico City.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
        <a href="#cite_note-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Genetics">
        Genetics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Genetics">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       According to a genetic study done in 2011, the average genetic composition of people from Mexico City is 65% European, 31% Native American, and 3% African.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
        <a href="#cite_note-96">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Nationality">
        Nationality
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Nationality">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       On the other hand, Mexico City is also home to large communities of
       <a href="/wiki/Expatriate" title="Expatriate">
        expatriates
       </a>
       and immigrants, most notably from the rest of North America (
       <a href="/wiki/Americans" title="Americans">
        U.S.
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Canadians" title="Canadians">
        Canada
       </a>
       ), from South America (mainly from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Argentine_people" title="Argentine people">
        Argentina
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_people" title="Colombian people">
        Colombia
       </a>
       , but also from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_people" title="Brazilian people">
        Brazil
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chilean_people" title="Chilean people">
        Chile
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uruguayan_people" title="Uruguayan people">
        Uruguay
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Venezuelan_people" title="Venezuelan people">
        Venezuela
       </a>
       ), from Central America and the Caribbean (mainly from
       <a href="/wiki/Cubans" title="Cubans">
        Cuba
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Guatemala" title="Demographics of Guatemala">
        Guatemala
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Salvadorans" title="List of Salvadorans">
        El Salvador
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Haitian_people" title="Haitian people">
        Haiti
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Hondurans" title="Hondurans">
        Honduras
       </a>
       ); from Europe (mainly from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_people" title="Spanish people">
        Spain
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Germans" title="Germans">
        Germany
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Swiss_people" title="Swiss people">
        Switzerland
       </a>
       , but also from
