       <a href="/wiki/Czechs" title="Czechs">
        Czech Republic
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_people" title="Hungarian people">
        Hungary
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/French_people" title="French people">
        France
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_people" title="Italian people">
        Italy
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Irish_people" title="Irish people">
        Ireland
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dutch_people" title="Dutch people">
        the Netherlands
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polish_people" title="Polish people">
        Poland
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Romanians" title="Romanians">
        Romania
       </a>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-extranjeros_97-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-extranjeros-97">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
        <a href="#cite_note-98">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       from the Middle East (mainly from
       <a href="/wiki/Egyptians" title="Egyptians">
        Egypt
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Lebanese_people_in_Mexico" title="List of Lebanese people in Mexico">
        Lebanon
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syrian_people" title="Syrian people">
        Syria
       </a>
       );
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
        <a href="#cite_note-99">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and recently from Asia-Pacific (mainly from
       <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people" title="Chinese people">
        China
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Korean_people" title="Korean people">
        South Korea
       </a>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Historically since the era of
       <a href="/wiki/New_Spain" title="New Spain">
        New Spain
       </a>
       , many
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filipino_people" title="Filipino people">
        Filipinos
       </a>
       settled in the city and have become integrated in Mexican society. While no official figures have been reported,
       <a href="/wiki/Census" title="Census">
        population estimates
       </a>
       of each of these communities are quite significant.
      </p>
      <p>
       Mexico City is home to the largest population of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Demographics_of_the_United_States" title="Demographics of the United States">
        U.S. Americans
       </a>
       living outside the United States. Current estimates are as high as 700,000 U.S. Americans living in Mexico City, while in 1999 the U.S. Bureau of Consular Affairs estimated over 440,000 Americans lived in the Mexico City Metropolitan Area.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
        <a href="#cite_note-102">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
        Religion
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Religion">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The majority (82%) of the residents in Mexico City are Roman Catholic, higher than the national percentage, though it has been decreasing over the last decades.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Many other religions and philosophies are also practiced in the city: many different types of
       <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">
        Protestant
       </a>
       groups, different types of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Mexico" title="History of the Jews in Mexico">
        Jewish communities
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">
        Buddhist
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic" title="Islamic">
        Islamic
       </a>
       and other
       <a href="/wiki/Spirituality" title="Spirituality">
        spiritual
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philosophical" title="Philosophical">
        philosophical
       </a>
       groups. There are also growing
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2016)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       numbers of irreligious people, whether agnostic or atheist.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">
        Transportation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Transportation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Public_transportation">
        Public transportation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Public transportation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FE-10_06.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2460" data-file-width="3280" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/FE-10_06.jpg/220px-FE-10_06.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/FE-10_06.jpg/330px-FE-10_06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/FE-10_06.jpg/440px-FE-10_06.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FE-10_06.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Metro" title="Mexico City Metro">
          Mexico City Metro
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Mexico City has many modes of public transportation, from the metro (subway) system, to suburban rail, light rail, regular buses, BRT (bus rapid transit), 'pesero' minibuses, and trolleybuses, to bike share.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Metro">
        Metro
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Metro">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Metro" title="Mexico City Metro">
        Mexico City Metro
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Mexico City is served by the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Metro" title="Mexico City Metro">
         Sistema de Transporte Colectivo
        </a>
       </i>
       , a 225.9 km (140 mi)
       <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">
        metro
       </a>
       system, which is the largest in Latin America. The first portions were opened in 1969 and it has expanded to 12 lines with
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Mexico_City_metro_stations" title="List of Mexico City metro stations">
        195 stations
       </a>
       . The metro transports 4.4 million people every day. It is the 8th busiest metro system in the world, behind Tokyo (10.0 million), Beijing (9.3 million), Shanghai (7.8 million), Seoul (7.3 million), Moscow (6.7 million), Guangzhou (6.2 million), and New York City (4.9 million).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
        <a href="#cite_note-104">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is heavily subsidized, and has some of the lowest fares in the world, each trip costing 5.00
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_peso" title="Mexican peso">
        pesos
       </a>
       (roughly 0.27 USD) from 05:00 am to midnight. Several stations display
       <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_era" title="Pre-Columbian era">
        pre-Columbian
       </a>
       artifacts and architecture that were discovered during the metro's construction.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2008)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       However, the metro covers less than half of the total urban area. The Metro stations are also differentiated by the use of icons and glyphs which were created for the illiterate, a unique system that has become iconic characteristic of Mexico City. Each icon was developed based on historical (characters, sites, pre-Hispanic motifs), linguistic, symbolic (glyphs) or geographic references. A complementary system of icons was used for the Metrobús (BRT) stops.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Suburban_rail">
        Suburban rail
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Suburban rail">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       A suburban rail system, the
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ferrocarril_Suburbano_de_la_Zona_Metropolitana_del_Valle_de_M%C3%A9xico" title="Ferrocarril Suburbano de la Zona Metropolitana del Valle de México">
         Tren Suburbano
        </a>
       </i>
       serves the metropolitan area, beyond the reach of the
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Metro" title="Mexico City Metro">
        metro
       </a>
       , currently with only one line serving to municipalities such as
       <a href="/wiki/Tlalnepantla_de_Baz" title="Tlalnepantla de Baz">
        Tlalnepantla
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuautitl%C3%A1n_Izcalli,_Mexico_State" title="Cuautitlán Izcalli, Mexico State">
        Cuautitlán Izcalli
       </a>
       , but with future lines planned to serve e.g.
       <a href="/wiki/Chalco_de_D%C3%ADaz_Covarrubias" title="Chalco de Díaz Covarrubias">
        Chalco
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Los_Reyes_Acaquilpan" title="Los Reyes Acaquilpan">
        La Paz
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Peseros">
        Peseros
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Peseros">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eco3292.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="540" data-file-width="960" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Eco3292.jpg/220px-Eco3292.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Eco3292.jpg/330px-Eco3292.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Eco3292.jpg/440px-Eco3292.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eco3292.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A
         <i>
          pesero
         </i>
         or microbús
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Pesero" title="Pesero">
        Peseros
       </a>
       are typically half-length passenger buses (known as
       <i>
        microbús
       </i>
       ) that sit 22 passengers and stand up to 28. As of 2007
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , the approximately 28,000 peseros carried up to 60 percent of the city's passengers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
        <a href="#cite_note-105">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In August 2016, Mayor Mancera announced that new pesero vehicle and concessions would be eliminated completely unless they were ecologically friendly vehicles,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
        <a href="#cite_note-107">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and in October 2011 the city's Secretary of Mobility Héctor Serrano states that by the end of the current administration (2018) there would no longer by any peseros/microbuses circulating at all, and that new full-sized buses would take over the routes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-excelsior-pesero_108-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-excelsior-pesero-108">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Mid-size_buses">
        Mid-size buses
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Mid-size buses">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       In 2014, the city launched so-called "Bus Rapid Service", with mid-sized
       <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">
        Mercedes-Benz
       </a>
       Boxer buses carrying 75-85 passengers
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
        <a href="#cite_note-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
       painted purple-on-white, replacing 'peseros' on certain groups of routes. Operation is a concession to the private firms (SAUSA, COTOBUSA, TREPSA) instead of to individual vehicle operators.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
        <a href="#cite_note-112">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
        <a href="#cite_note-113">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Full-sized_buses">
        Full-sized buses
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Full-sized buses">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       City agency M1, formerly Red de Transporte de Pasajeros (RTP),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       operates various networks of large buses including regular, Ecobús,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Circuito_Bicentenario&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Circuito Bicentenario (page does not exist)">
        Circuito Bicentenario
       </a>
       , Atenea, Express, school and night routes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2016, more bus routes were added to replace pesero routes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-excelsior-pesero_108-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-excelsior-pesero-108">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2016, the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=SVBUS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="SVBUS (page does not exist)">
        SVBUS
       </a>
       express bus service was launched, with limited stops and utilizing the city's toll roads on the second-level of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Perif%C3%A9rico" title="Periférico">
        Periférico
       </a>
       ring road and
       <a href="/wiki/Superv%C3%ADa_Poniente" title="Supervía Poniente">
        Supervía Poniente
       </a>
       and connecting
       <a href="/wiki/Toreo_Parque_Central" title="Toreo Parque Central">
        Toreo
       </a>
       /
       <a href="/wiki/Metro_Cuatro_Caminos" title="Metro Cuatro Caminos">
        Cuatro Caminos
       </a>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/Santa_Fe,_Mexico_City" title="Santa Fe, Mexico City">
        Santa Fe
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/San_Jer%C3%B3nimo_L%C3%ADdice" title="San Jerónimo Lídice">
        San Jerónimo Lídice
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Santa_Mar%C3%ADa_Tepepan" title="Santa María Tepepan">
        Tepepan
       </a>
       near
       <a href="/wiki/Xochimilco" title="Xochimilco">
        Xochimilco
       </a>
       in the southeast.
      </p>
      <p>
       Suburban buses also leave from the city's main intercity bus stations.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Bus_rapid_transit">
        Bus rapid transit
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Bus rapid transit">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Estaci%C3%B3n_SetDominguez.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="234" data-file-width="312" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Estaci%C3%B3n_SetDominguez.jpg/220px-Estaci%C3%B3n_SetDominguez.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9c/Estaci%C3%B3n_SetDominguez.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Estaci%C3%B3n_SetDominguez.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Metrob%C3%BAs" title="Mexico City Metrobús">
          Metrobús
         </a>
         rapid transit bus stop station at Indios Verdes
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The city's first
       <a href="/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit" title="Bus rapid transit">
        bus rapid transit
       </a>
       line, the
       <b>
        <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Metrob%C3%BAs" title="Mexico City Metrobús">
         Metrobús
        </a>
       </b>
       , began operation in June 2005, along
       <a href="/wiki/Avenida_de_los_Insurgentes" title="Avenida de los Insurgentes">
        Avenida Insurgentes
       </a>
       . More and more lines opened and as of mid-2017 there are 6 routes with a 7th planned along
       <a href="/wiki/Paseo_de_la_Reforma" title="Paseo de la Reforma">
        Paseo de la Reforma
       </a>
       to connect
       <a href="/wiki/Santa_Fe,_Mexico_City" title="Santa Fe, Mexico City">
        Santa Fe
       </a>
       with the city center and points north.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As each line opened, the 'pesero' minibuses were removed from each route, in order to reduce pollution and commute times. As of mid-2017, there were 568
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Metrobús buses. In late 2016 they transported an average of 1.1 million passengers daily.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <b>
        <a href="/wiki/Mexib%C3%BAs" title="Mexibús">
         Mexibús
        </a>
       </b>
       provides 3 bus rapid transit lines connecting
       <a href="/wiki/Metro_Ciudad_Azteca" title="Metro Ciudad Azteca">
        Metro Ciudad Azteca
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Metro_Pantitl%C3%A1n" title="Metro Pantitlán">
        Metro Pantitlán
       </a>
       with
       <a href="/wiki/Cuautitl%C3%A1n" title="Cuautitlán">
        Cuautitlán
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ecatepec" title="Ecatepec">
        Ecatepec
       </a>
       and other suburban areas in the State of Mexico.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="Trolleybus.2C_light_rail.2C_streetcars">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Trolleybus,_light_rail,_streetcars">
        Trolleybus, light rail, streetcars
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Trolleybus, light rail, streetcars">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_City%27s_Eje_Central_with_trolleybus_in_contraflow_lane_(2013).jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Mexico_City%27s_Eje_Central_with_trolleybus_in_contraflow_lane_%282013%29.jpg/220px-Mexico_City%27s_Eje_Central_with_trolleybus_in_contraflow_lane_%282013%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Mexico_City%27s_Eje_Central_with_trolleybus_in_contraflow_lane_%282013%29.jpg/330px-Mexico_City%27s_Eje_Central_with_trolleybus_in_contraflow_lane_%282013%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Mexico_City%27s_Eje_Central_with_trolleybus_in_contraflow_lane_%282013%29.jpg/440px-Mexico_City%27s_Eje_Central_with_trolleybus_in_contraflow_lane_%282013%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mexico_City%27s_Eje_Central_with_trolleybus_in_contraflow_lane_(2013).jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         An
         <a href="/wiki/Servicio_de_Transportes_El%C3%A9ctricos" title="Servicio de Transportes Eléctricos">
          STE
         </a>
         trolleybus using a transit-only
         <a href="/wiki/Contraflow_lane" title="Contraflow lane">
          contraflow lane
         </a>
         on
         <a href="/wiki/Eje_Central" title="Eje Central">
          Eje Central
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Electric transport other than the metro also exists, in the form of several
       <a href="/wiki/Trolleybuses_in_Mexico_City" title="Trolleybuses in Mexico City">
        Mexico City trolleybus
       </a>
       routes and the
       <a href="/wiki/Xochimilco_Light_Rail" title="Xochimilco Light Rail">
        Xochimilco Light Rail
       </a>
       line, both of which are operated by
       <a href="/wiki/Servicio_de_Transportes_El%C3%A9ctricos" title="Servicio de Transportes Eléctricos">
        Servicio de Transportes Eléctricos
       </a>
       . The central area's last
       <a href="/wiki/Tram" title="Tram">
        streetcar
       </a>
       line (tramway, or
       <i>
        <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tranv%C3%ADa" title="es:Tranvía">
         tranvía
        </a>
       </i>
       ) closed in 1979.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Roads_and_car_transport">
        Roads and car transport
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Roads and car transport">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vista_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_desde_Periferico_y_Paseo_de_la_Reforma.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1936" data-file-width="2592" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Vista_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_desde_Periferico_y_Paseo_de_la_Reforma.JPG/220px-Vista_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_desde_Periferico_y_Paseo_de_la_Reforma.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Vista_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_desde_Periferico_y_Paseo_de_la_Reforma.JPG/330px-Vista_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_desde_Periferico_y_Paseo_de_la_Reforma.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Vista_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_desde_Periferico_y_Paseo_de_la_Reforma.JPG/440px-Vista_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_desde_Periferico_y_Paseo_de_la_Reforma.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vista_de_la_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_desde_Periferico_y_Paseo_de_la_Reforma.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         View of the
         <a href="/wiki/Anillo_Perif%C3%A9rico" title="Anillo Periférico">
          Anillo Periférico
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Paseo_de_la_Reforma" title="Paseo de la Reforma">
          Paseo de la Reforma
         </a>
         near
         <a href="/wiki/Chapultepec" title="Chapultepec">
          Chapultepec
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In the late 1970s many arterial roads were redesigned as
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Eje_vial" title="Eje vial">
         ejes viales
        </a>
       </i>
       ; high-volume one-way roads that cross, in theory, Mexico City proper from side to side. The
       <i>
        eje vial
       </i>
       network is based on a quasi-
       <a href="/wiki/Cartesian_coordinate_system" title="Cartesian coordinate system">
        Cartesian
       </a>
       grid, with the
       <i>
        ejes
       </i>
       themselves being called
       <i>
        Eje 1 Poniente
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        Eje Central
       </i>
       , and
       <i>
        Eje 1 Oriente
       </i>
       , for example, for the north-south roads, and
       <i>
        Eje 2 Sur
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Eje 3 Norte
       </i>
       , for example, for east-west roads. Ring roads are the
       <a href="/wiki/Circuito_Interior" title="Circuito Interior">
        Circuito Interior
       </a>
       (inner ring),
       <a href="/wiki/Anillo_Perif%C3%A9rico" title="Anillo Periférico">
        Anillo Periférico
       </a>
       ; the
       <a href="/wiki/Circuito_Exterior_Mexiquense" title="Circuito Exterior Mexiquense">
        Circuito Exterior Mexiquense
       </a>
       ("State of Mexico outer loop") toll road skirting the northeastern and eastern edges of the metropolitan area,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Autopista_Chamapa-La_Venta" title="Autopista Chamapa-La Venta">
        Chamapa-La Venta
       </a>
       toll road skirting the northwestern edge, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Arco_Norte" title="Arco Norte">
        Arco Norte
       </a>
       completely bypassing the metropolitan area in an arc from northwest (
       <a href="/wiki/Atlacomulco" title="Atlacomulco">
        Atlacomulco
       </a>
       ) to north (
       <a href="/wiki/Tula_de_Allende" title="Tula de Allende">
        Tula, Hidalgo
       </a>
       ) to east (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puebla,_Puebla" title="Puebla, Puebla">
        Puebla
       </a>
       ). A second level (where tolls are charged) of the Periférico, colloquially called the
       <i>
        segundo piso
       </i>
       ("second floor"), was officially opened in 2012, with sections still being completed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
        <a href="#cite_note-122">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Viaducto_Miguel_Alem%C3%A1n" title="Viaducto Miguel Alemán">
        Viaducto Miguel Alemán
       </a>
       crosses the city east-west from Observatorio to the airport. In 2013 the
       <a href="/wiki/Superv%C3%ADa_Poniente" title="Supervía Poniente">
        Supervía Poniente
       </a>
       opened, a toll road linking the new
       <a href="/wiki/Santa_Fe,_Mexico_City" title="Santa Fe, Mexico City">
        Santa Fe
       </a>
       business district with southwestern Mexico City.
      </p>
      <p>
       There is an environmental program, called
       <a href="/wiki/Hoy_No_Circula" title="Hoy No Circula">
        Hoy No Circula
       </a>
       ("Today Does Not Run", or "One Day without a Car"), whereby vehicles that have not passed emissions testing are restricted from circulating on certain days according to the ending digit of their
       <a href="/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plate" title="Vehicle registration plate">
        license plates
       </a>
       ; this in an attempt to cut down on pollution and traffic congestion. While in 2003, the program still restricted 40% of vehicles in the metropolitan area,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
        <a href="#cite_note-123">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with the adoption of stricter emissions standards in 2001 and 2006,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
        <a href="#cite_note-124">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       in practice, these days most vehicles are exempt from the circulation restrictions as long as they pass regular emissions tests.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Parking">
        Parking
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Parking">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Parking_in_Mexico_City" title="Parking in Mexico City">
        Parking in Mexico City
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Street parking in urban neighborhoods is mostly controlled by the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Franelero" title="Franelero">
         franeleros
        </a>
       </i>
       a.k.a. "
       <i>
        viene vienes
       </i>
       " (lit. "come on, come on"), who ask drivers for a fee to park, in theory to guard the car, but with the implicit threat that the
       <i>
        franelero
       </i>
       will damage the car if the fee is not paid. Double parking is common (with
       <i>
        franeleros
       </i>
       moving the cars as required), impeding on the available lanes for traffic to pass. In order to mitigate that and other problems and to raise revenue,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
       721 parking meters (as of October 2013), have been installed in the west-central neighborhoods
       <a href="/wiki/Lomas_de_Chapultepec" title="Lomas de Chapultepec">
        Lomas de Chapultepec
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Condesa" title="Condesa">
        Condesa
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Colonia_Roma" title="Colonia Roma">
        Roma
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polanco" title="Polanco">
        Polanco
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Anzures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Anzures (page does not exist)">
        Anzures
       </a>
       , in operation from 8 AM to 8 PM on weekdays and charging a rate of 2 pesos per 15 minutes, with offenders' cars booted, costing about 500 pesos to remove. 30 percent of the monthly 16 million-peso (as of October 2013) income from the parking-meter system (named "ecoParq") is earmarked for neighborhood improvements. The granting of the license for all zones exclusively to a new company without experience in operating parking meters, Operadora de Estacionamientos Bicentenario, has generated controversy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
        <a href="#cite_note-127">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cycling">
        Cycling
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Cycling">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/EcoBici_(Mexico_City)" title="EcoBici (Mexico City)">
        EcoBici (Mexico City)
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ECOBICI1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="798" height="331" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/ECOBICI1.jpg/220px-ECOBICI1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/ECOBICI1.jpg/330px-ECOBICI1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/ECOBICI1.jpg/440px-ECOBICI1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ECOBICI1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Bicycles available for rental in
         <a href="/wiki/Zona_Rosa,_Mexico_City" title="Zona Rosa, Mexico City">
          Zona Rosa
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The local government continuously strives for a reduction of massive traffic congestion, and has increased incentives for making a
       <a href="/wiki/Bicycle-friendly" title="Bicycle-friendly">
        bicycle-friendly
       </a>
       city. This includes North America's second-largest
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bicycle_sharing_system" title="Bicycle sharing system">
        bicycle sharing system
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/EcoBici_(Mexico_City)" title="EcoBici (Mexico City)">
        EcoBici
       </a>
       , launched in 2010, in which registered residents can get bicycles for 45 minutes with a pre-paid subscription of 300 pesos a year. There are, as of September 2013, 276 stations with 4,000 bicycles across an area stretching from the
       <a href="/wiki/Historic_center_of_Mexico_City" title="Historic center of Mexico City">
        Historic center
       </a>
       to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polanco_(Mexico)" title="Polanco (Mexico)">
        Polanco
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
        <a href="#cite_note-128">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       within 300 metres (980 feet) of one another and are fully automatic using a transponder based card. Bicycle-service users have access to several permanent
       <a href="/wiki/Ciclov%C3%ADa" title="Ciclovía">
        Ciclovías
       </a>
       (dedicated bike paths/lanes/streets), including ones along
       <a href="/wiki/Paseo_de_la_Reforma" title="Paseo de la Reforma">
        Paseo de la Reforma
       </a>
       and Avenida Chapultepec as well as one running 59 kilometres (37 miles) from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polanco_(Mexico)" title="Polanco (Mexico)">
        Polanco
       </a>
       to
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Fierro_del_Toro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Fierro del Toro (page does not exist)">
        Fierro del Toro
       </a>
       , which is located south of
       <a href="/wiki/Cumbres_del_Ajusco_National_Park" title="Cumbres del Ajusco National Park">
        Cumbres del Ajusco National Park
       </a>
       , near the
       <a href="/wiki/Morelos" title="Morelos">
        Morelos
       </a>
       state line.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
        <a href="#cite_note-129">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
        <a href="#cite_note-130">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The city's initiative is inspired by forward thinking examples, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">
        Denmark
       </a>
       's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Copenhagenization_(bicycling)" title="Copenhagenization (bicycling)">
        Copenhagenization
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Intercity_buses">
        Intercity buses
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Intercity buses">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The city has four major bus stations (North, South, Observatorio, TAPO), which comprise one of the world's largest transportation agglomerations, with bus service to many cities across the country and international connections. There are some intercity buses that leave directly from the
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_International_Airport" title="Mexico City International Airport">
        Mexico City International Airport
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Airports">
        Airports
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Airports">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AICM_AIR_T2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="886" height="179" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/AICM_AIR_T2.jpg/220px-AICM_AIR_T2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/AICM_AIR_T2.jpg/330px-AICM_AIR_T2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/AICM_AIR_T2.jpg/440px-AICM_AIR_T2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:AICM_AIR_T2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Terminal 2 of the Mexico City airport
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Mexico City is served by
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_International_Airport" title="Mexico City International Airport">
        Mexico City International Airport
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Air_Transport_Association_airport_code" title="International Air Transport Association airport code">
        IATA Airport Code
       </a>
       : MEX). This airport is Latin America's
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Latin_America" title="List of the busiest airports in Latin America">
        busiest
       </a>
       , with daily flights to United States and Canada, Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean, South America, Europe and Asia.
       <a href="/wiki/Aerom%C3%A9xico" title="Aeroméxico">
        Aeroméxico
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/SkyTeam" title="SkyTeam">
        Skyteam
       </a>
       ) is based at this airport, and provide codeshare agreements with non-Mexican airlines that span the entire globe. The airport is also a hub for
       <a href="/wiki/Volaris" title="Volaris">
        Volaris
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Interjet" title="Interjet">
        Interjet
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Aeromar" title="Aeromar">
        Aeromar
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2016, the airport handled almost 42 million passengers, about 3.3 million more than the year before.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
        <a href="#cite_note-131">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This traffic exceeds the current capacity of the airport, which has historically centralized the majority of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Air_traffic" title="Air traffic">
        air traffic
       </a>
       in the country. An alternate option is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lic._Adolfo_L%C3%B3pez_Mateos_International_Airport" title="Lic. Adolfo López Mateos International Airport">
        Lic. Adolfo López Mateos International Airport
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Air_Transport_Association_airport_code" title="International Air Transport Association airport code">
        IATA Airport Code
       </a>
       : TLC) in nearby
       <a href="/wiki/Toluca" title="Toluca">
        Toluca
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/State_of_Mexico" title="State of Mexico">
        State of Mexico
       </a>
       , although due to several airlines' decisions to terminate service to TLC, the airport has seen a passenger drop to just over 700,000 passengers in 2014 from over 2.1 million passengers just four years prior.
      </p>
      <p>
       In the Mexico City airport, the government engaged in an extensive restructuring program that includes the addition of a new second terminal, which began operations in 2007, and the enlargement of four other airports (at the nearby cities of
       <a href="/wiki/Toluca" title="Toluca">
        Toluca
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quer%C3%A9taro,_Quer%C3%A9taro" title="Querétaro, Querétaro">
        Querétaro
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puebla,_Puebla" title="Puebla, Puebla">
        Puebla
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Cuernavaca" title="Cuernavaca">
        Cuernavaca
       </a>
       ) that, along with Mexico City's airport, comprise the
       <i>
        Grupo Aeroportuario del Valle de México
       </i>
       , distributing traffic to different regions in Mexico. The city of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pachuca,_Hidalgo" title="Pachuca, Hidalgo">
        Pachuca
       </a>
       will also provide additional expansion to central Mexico's airport network.
      </p>
      <p>
       During his annual state-of-the-nation address on September 2, 2014,
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Mexico" title="President of Mexico">
        President of Mexico
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Pe%C3%B1a_Nieto" title="Enrique Peña Nieto">
        Enrique Peña Nieto
       </a>
       unveiled plans for a new international airport to ease the city's notorious air traffic congestion, tentatively slated for a 2018 opening. The new airport, which would have six runways, will cost $9.15 billion and would be built on vacant federal land east of Mexico City International Airport. Goals are to eventually handle 120 million passengers a year, which would make it the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by passenger traffic">
        busiest airport in the world
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
        <a href="#cite_note-133">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
        Culture
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Culture">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">
        Tourism
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Tourism">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="mbox-small plainlinks sistersitebox" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="193" data-file-width="193" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg/40px-Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg/60px-Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg/80px-Wikivoyage-Logo-v3-icon.svg.png 2x" width="40"/>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text plainlist">
         Wikivoyage has a travel guide for
         <i>
          <b>
           <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/Mexico_City#Q1489" title="wikivoyage:Mexico City">
            Mexico City
           </a>
          </b>
         </i>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Mexico City is a destination for many foreign tourists. Wikipedia's sister project
       <a href="/wiki/Wikivoyage" title="Wikivoyage">
        Wikivoyage
       </a>
       has useful information on tourism in Mexico City. The
       <a href="/wiki/Historic_center_of_Mexico_City" title="Historic center of Mexico City">
        Historic center of Mexico City
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Centro Histórico
       </i>
       ) and the "floating gardens" of
       <a href="/wiki/Xochimilco" title="Xochimilco">
        Xochimilco
       </a>
       in the southern borough have been declared
       <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
        World Heritage Sites
       </a>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">
        UNESCO
       </a>
       . Famous landmarks in the Historic Center include the
       <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%B3calo" title="Zócalo">
        Plaza de la Constitución
       </a>
       (Zócalo), the main central square with its epoch-contrasting Spanish-era
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Metropolitan_Cathedral" title="Mexico City Metropolitan Cathedral">
        Metropolitan Cathedral
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/National_Palace_(Mexico)" title="National Palace (Mexico)">
        National Palace
       </a>
       , ancient Aztec temple ruins
       <a href="/wiki/Templo_Mayor" title="Templo Mayor">
        Templo Mayor
       </a>
       ("Major Temple") and modern structures, all within a few steps of one another. (The Templo Mayor was discovered in 1978 while workers were digging to place underground electric cables).
      </p>
      <p>
       The most recognizable icon of Mexico City is the golden
       <a href="/wiki/Angel_of_Independence" title="Angel of Independence">
        Angel of Independence
       </a>
       on the wide, elegant avenue
       <a href="/wiki/Paseo_de_la_Reforma" title="Paseo de la Reforma">
        Paseo de la Reforma
       </a>
       , modeled by the order of the Emperor
       <a href="/wiki/Maximilian_I_of_Mexico" title="Maximilian I of Mexico">
        Maximilian of Mexico
       </a>
       after the
       <a href="/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es" title="Champs-Élysées">
        Champs-Élysées
       </a>
       in Paris. This avenue was designed over the Americas' oldest known major roadway in the 19th century to connect the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Palace_(Mexico)" title="National Palace (Mexico)">
        National Palace
       </a>
       (seat of government) with the
       <a href="/wiki/Chapultepec_Castle" title="Chapultepec Castle">
        Castle of Chapultepec
       </a>
       , the imperial residence. Today, this avenue is an important financial district in which the
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Stock_Exchange" title="Mexican Stock Exchange">
        Mexican Stock Exchange
       </a>
       and several
       <a href="/wiki/Corporate_headquarters" title="Corporate headquarters">
        corporate headquarters
       </a>
       are located. Another important avenue is the
       <a href="/wiki/Avenida_de_los_Insurgentes" title="Avenida de los Insurgentes">
        Avenida de los Insurgentes
       </a>
       , which extends 28.8 km (17.9 mi) and is one of the longest single avenues in the world.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Chapultepec" title="Chapultepec">
        Chapultepec
       </a>
       Park houses the
       <a href="/wiki/Chapultepec_Castle" title="Chapultepec Castle">
        Chapultepec Castle
       </a>
       , now a museum on a hill that overlooks the park and its numerous museums, monuments and the national zoo and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museo_Nacional_de_Antropolog%C3%ADa" title="Museo Nacional de Antropología">
        National Museum of Anthropology
       </a>
       (which houses the
       <a href="/wiki/Aztec_calendar_stone" title="Aztec calendar stone">
        Aztec Calendar Stone
       </a>
       ). Another piece of architecture is the
       <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">
        Fine Arts Palace
       </a>
       , a white marble theatre/museum whose weight is such that it has gradually been sinking into the soft ground below. Its construction began during the presidency of
       <a href="/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz" title="Porfirio Díaz">
        Porfirio Díaz
       </a>
       and ended in 1934, after being interrupted by the
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">
        Mexican Revolution
       </a>
       in the 1920s. The
       <a href="/wiki/Plaza_de_las_Tres_Culturas" title="Plaza de las Tres Culturas">
        Plaza of the Three Cultures
       </a>
       in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tlatelolco_(Mexico_City)" title="Tlatelolco (Mexico City)">
        Tlatelolco
       </a>
       neighbourhood, and the shrine and
       <a href="/wiki/Basilica" title="Basilica">
        Basilicas
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Guadalupe" title="Our Lady of Guadalupe">
        Our Lady of Guadalupe
       </a>
       are also important sites. There is a
       <a href="/wiki/Double-decker_bus" title="Double-decker bus">
        double-decker bus
       </a>
       , known as the "Turibus", that circles most of these sites, and has timed audio describing the sites in multiple languages as they are passed.
      </p>
      <p>
       In addition, the city has about 160 museums—the world's greatest single metropolitan concentration
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
        <a href="#cite_note-134">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
       —over 100
       <a href="/wiki/Art_museum" title="Art museum">
        art galleries
       </a>
       , and some 30
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_concert_halls" title="List of concert halls">
        concert halls
       </a>
       , all of which maintain a constant cultural activity during the whole year. It has either the third or fourth-highest number of theatres in the world after New York, London and perhaps Toronto. Many areas (e.g. Palacio Nacional and the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=National_Institute_of_Cardiology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="National Institute of Cardiology (page does not exist)">
        National Institute of Cardiology
       </a>
       ) have murals painted by
       <a href="/wiki/Diego_Rivera" title="Diego Rivera">
        Diego Rivera
       </a>
       . He and his wife
       <a href="/wiki/Frida_Kahlo" title="Frida Kahlo">
        Frida Kahlo
       </a>
       lived in
       <a href="/wiki/Coyoac%C3%A1n" title="Coyoacán">
        Coyoacán
       </a>
       , where several of their homes, studios, and art collections are open to the public. The house where
       <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">
        Leon Trotsky
       </a>
       was initially granted asylum and finally murdered in 1940 is also in Coyoacán.
      </p>
      <p>
       In addition, there are several restored
       <i>
        haciendas
       </i>
       that are now restaurants, such as the San Ángel Inn, the Hacienda de Tlalpan and the Hacienda de los Morales.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Art">
        Art
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Art">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_art" title="Mexican art">
        Mexican art
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_-_Mural_La_Nueva_Democracia_Siqueiros_1.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_-_Mural_La_Nueva_Democracia_Siqueiros_1.jpg/220px-Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_-_Mural_La_Nueva_Democracia_Siqueiros_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_-_Mural_La_Nueva_Democracia_Siqueiros_1.jpg/330px-Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_-_Mural_La_Nueva_Democracia_Siqueiros_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_-_Mural_La_Nueva_Democracia_Siqueiros_1.jpg/440px-Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_-_Mural_La_Nueva_Democracia_Siqueiros_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes_-_Mural_La_Nueva_Democracia_Siqueiros_1.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Mural in the Palacio de Bellas Artes by
         <a href="/wiki/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros" title="David Alfaro Siqueiros">
          David Alfaro Siqueiros
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Having been capital of a vast pre-Hispanic empire, and also the capital of richest viceroyalty within the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">
        Spanish Empire
       </a>
       (ruling over a vast territory in the Americas and
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_West_Indies" title="Spanish West Indies">
        Spanish West Indies
       </a>
       ), and, finally, the capital of the United Mexican States, Mexico City has a rich history of
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_art" title="Mexican art">
        artistic expression
       </a>
       . Since the mesoamerican pre-Classical period the inhabitants of the settlements around Lake Texcoco produced many works of art and complex craftsmanship, some of which are today displayed at the world-renowned
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museo_Nacional_de_Antropolog%C3%ADa" title="Museo Nacional de Antropología">
        National Museum of Anthropology
       </a>
       and the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Templo_Mayor" title="Templo Mayor">
         Templo Mayor
        </a>
       </i>
       museum. While many pieces of pottery and stone-engraving have survived, the great majority of the Amerindian iconography was destroyed during the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conquest_of_Mexico" title="Conquest of Mexico">
        Conquest of Mexico
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Much of the early colonial art stemmed from the codices (Aztec illustrated books), aiming to recover and preserve some Aztec and other Amerindian iconography and history. From then, artistic expressions in Mexico were mostly religious in theme. The
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Metropolitan_Cathedral" title="Mexico City Metropolitan Cathedral">
        Metropolitan Cathedral
       </a>
       still displays works by
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Juan_de_Rojas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Juan de Rojas (page does not exist)">
        Juan de Rojas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Juan_Correa" title="Juan Correa">
        Juan Correa
       </a>
       and an
       <a href="/wiki/Oil_painting" title="Oil painting">
        oil painting
       </a>
       whose authorship has been attributed to
       <a href="/wiki/Bartolom%C3%A9_Esteban_Murillo" title="Bartolomé Esteban Murillo">
        Murillo
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       Secular works of art of this period include the
       <a href="/wiki/Equestrian_statue" title="Equestrian statue">
        equestrian sculpture
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Charles_IV_of_Spain" title="Charles IV of Spain">
        Charles IV of Spain
       </a>
       , locally known as
       <i>
        El Caballito
       </i>
       ("The little horse"). This piece, in bronze, was the work of
       <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Tols%C3%A1" title="Manuel Tolsá">
        Manuel Tolsá
       </a>
       and it has been placed at the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Plaza_Tols%C3%A1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Plaza Tolsá (page does not exist)">
        Plaza Tolsá
       </a>
       , in front of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Mineria" title="Palacio de Mineria">
        Palacio de Mineria
       </a>
       (
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Mining_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Mining Palace (page does not exist)">
        Mining Palace
       </a>
       ). Directly in front of this building is the beautiful
       <a href="/wiki/Museo_Nacional_de_Arte" title="Museo Nacional de Arte">
        Museo Nacional de Arte
       </a>
       (Munal) (the National Museum of Art).
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ReceptHallMUNAL.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3872" data-file-width="2592" height="329" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/ReceptHallMUNAL.JPG/220px-ReceptHallMUNAL.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/ReceptHallMUNAL.JPG/330px-ReceptHallMUNAL.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/ReceptHallMUNAL.JPG/440px-ReceptHallMUNAL.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ReceptHallMUNAL.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Receptions hall at the
         <a href="/wiki/Museo_Nacional_de_Arte" title="Museo Nacional de Arte">
          Museo Nacional de Arte
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       During the 19th century, an important producer of art was the Academia de San Carlos (
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=San_Carlos_Art_Academy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="San Carlos Art Academy (page does not exist)">
        San Carlos Art Academy
       </a>
       ), founded during colonial times, and which later became the Escuela Nacional de Artes Plásticas (the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_School_of_Arts_(UNAM)" title="National School of Arts (UNAM)">
        National School of Arts
       </a>
       ) including painting, sculpture and graphic design, one of UNAM's
       <a href="/wiki/Art_school" title="Art school">
        art schools
       </a>
       . Many of the works produced by the students and faculty of that time are now displayed in the Museo Nacional de San Carlos (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_San_Carlos" title="National Museum of San Carlos">
        National Museum of San Carlos
       </a>
       ). One of the students,
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Velasco_G%C3%B3mez" title="José María Velasco Gómez">
        José María Velasco
       </a>
       , is considered one of the greatest Mexican landscape painters of the 19th century.
       <a href="/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz" title="Porfirio Díaz">
        Porfirio Díaz
       </a>
       's regime sponsored arts, especially those that followed the French school. Popular arts in the form of cartoons and illustrations flourished, e.g. those of
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Guadalupe_Posada" title="José Guadalupe Posada">
        José Guadalupe Posada
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Manuel_Manilla&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Manuel Manilla (page does not exist)">
        Manuel Manilla
       </a>
       . The permanent collection of the San Carlos Museum also includes paintings by European masters such as Rembrandt, Velázquez, Murillo, and Rubens.
      </p>
      <p>
       After the
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Revolution" title="Mexican Revolution">
        Mexican Revolution
       </a>
       , an
       <a href="/wiki/Avant-garde" title="Avant-garde">
        avant-garde
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Art_movement" title="Art movement">
        artistic movement
       </a>
       originated in Mexico City:
       <a href="/wiki/Mural" title="Mural">
        muralism
       </a>
       . Many of the works of muralists
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Clemente_Orozco" title="José Clemente Orozco">
        José Clemente Orozco
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/David_Alfaro_Siqueiros" title="David Alfaro Siqueiros">
        David Alfaro Siqueiros
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Diego_Rivera" title="Diego Rivera">
        Diego Rivera
       </a>
       are displayed in numerous buildings in the city, most notably at the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Palace_(Mexico)" title="National Palace (Mexico)">
        National Palace
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">
        Palacio de Bellas Artes
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Frida_Kahlo" title="Frida Kahlo">
        Frida Kahlo
       </a>
       , wife of Rivera, with a strong nationalist expression, was also one of the most renowned of Mexican painters. Her house has become a museum that displays many of her works.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The former home of Rivera muse
       <a href="/wiki/Dolores_Olmedo" title="Dolores Olmedo">
        Dolores Olmedo
       </a>
       houses the namesake museum. The facility is in Xochimilco borough in southern Mexico City and includes several buildings surrounded by sprawling manicured lawns. It houses a large collection of Rivera and Kahlo paintings and drawings, as well as living
       <i>
        Xoloizcuintles
       </i>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Hairless_Dog" title="Mexican Hairless Dog">
        Mexican Hairless Dog
       </a>
       ). It also regularly hosts small but important temporary exhibits of classical and
       <a href="/wiki/Modern_art" title="Modern art">
        modern art
       </a>
       (e.g. Venetian Masters and Contemporary New York artists).
      </p>
      <p>
       During the 20th century, many artists immigrated to Mexico City from different regions of Mexico, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Leopoldo_M%C3%A9ndez" title="Leopoldo Méndez">
        Leopoldo Méndez
       </a>
       , an engraver from Veracruz, who supported the creation of the socialist Taller de la Gráfica Popular (
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Popular_Graphics_Workshop&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Popular Graphics Workshop (page does not exist)">
        Popular Graphics Workshop
       </a>
       ), designed to help
       <a href="/wiki/Blue-collar_worker" title="Blue-collar worker">
        blue-collar
       </a>
       workers find a venue to express their art. Other painters came from abroad, such as
       <a href="/wiki/Catalonia" title="Catalonia">
        Catalan
       </a>
       painter
       <a href="/wiki/Remedios_Varo" title="Remedios Varo">
        Remedios Varo
       </a>
       and other Spanish and Jewish exiles. It was in the second half of the 20th century that the artistic movement began to drift apart from the Revolutionary theme.
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Luis_Cuevas" title="José Luis Cuevas">
        José Luis Cuevas
       </a>
       opted for a modernist style in contrast to the muralist movement associated with social politics.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Museums">
        Museums
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Museums">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:OutsideCasaAzul.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/OutsideCasaAzul.JPG/220px-OutsideCasaAzul.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/OutsideCasaAzul.JPG/330px-OutsideCasaAzul.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/OutsideCasaAzul.JPG/440px-OutsideCasaAzul.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:OutsideCasaAzul.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museo_Frida_Kahlo" title="Museo Frida Kahlo">
          Museo Frida Kahlo
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Museo_Soumaya_Plaza.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3632" data-file-width="4848" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Museo_Soumaya_Plaza.jpg/220px-Museo_Soumaya_Plaza.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Museo_Soumaya_Plaza.jpg/330px-Museo_Soumaya_Plaza.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Museo_Soumaya_Plaza.jpg/440px-Museo_Soumaya_Plaza.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Museo_Soumaya_Plaza.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Museo_Soumaya" title="Museo Soumaya">
          Museo Soumaya
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Mexico City has numerous museums dedicated to art, including Mexican colonial, modern and
       <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_art" title="Contemporary art">
        contemporary art
       </a>
       , and international art. The Museo Tamayo was opened in the mid-1980s to house the collection of international contemporary art donated by famed Mexican (born in the state of Oaxaca) painter
       <a href="/wiki/Rufino_Tamayo" title="Rufino Tamayo">
        Rufino Tamayo
       </a>
       . The collection includes pieces by Picasso, Klee, Kandinsky, Warhol and many others, though most of the collection is stored while visiting exhibits are shown. The
       <a href="/wiki/Museo_de_Arte_Moderno" title="Museo de Arte Moderno">
        Museo de Arte Moderno
       </a>
       (
       <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art" title="Museum of Modern Art">
        Museum of Modern Art
       </a>
       ) is a repository of Mexican artists from the 20th century, including Rivera, Orozco, Siqueiros, Kahlo,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gerzso&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gerzso (page does not exist)">
        Gerzso
       </a>
       , Carrington, Tamayo, among others, and also regularly hosts temporary exhibits of international modern art. In southern Mexico City, the Museo Carrillo Gil (
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Carrillo_Gil_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Carrillo Gil Museum (page does not exist)">
        Carrillo Gil Museum
       </a>
       ) showcases avant-garde artists, as does the University Museum/Contemporary Art (Museo Universitario Arte Contemporáneo – or MUAC), designed by famed Mexican architect
       <a href="/wiki/Teodoro_Gonz%C3%A1lez_de_Le%C3%B3n" title="Teodoro González de León">
        Teodoro González de León
       </a>
       , inaugurated in late 2008.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Museo_Soumaya" title="Museo Soumaya">
        Museo Soumaya
       </a>
       , named after the wife of Mexican magnate
       <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Slim" title="Carlos Slim">
        Carlos Slim
       </a>
       , has the largest private collection of original
       <a href="/wiki/Auguste_Rodin" title="Auguste Rodin">
        Rodin
       </a>
       sculptures outside Paris.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       It also has a large collection of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dal%C3%AD" title="Dalí">
        Dalí
       </a>
       sculptures, and recently began showing pieces in its masters collection including
       <a href="/wiki/El_Greco" title="El Greco">
        El Greco
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vel%C3%A1zquez" title="Velázquez">
        Velázquez
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Picasso" title="Picasso">
        Picasso
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Canaletto" title="Canaletto">
        Canaletto
       </a>
       . The museum inaugurated a new futuristic-design facility in 2011 just north of Polanco, while maintaining a smaller facility in
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Plaza_de_Loreto&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Plaza de Loreto (page does not exist)">
        Plaza de Loreto
       </a>
       in southern Mexico City. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colecci%C3%B3n_J%C3%BAmex" title="Colección Júmex">
        Colección Júmex
       </a>
       is a contemporary art museum located on the sprawling grounds of the
       <a href="/wiki/Jumex" title="Jumex">
        Jumex
       </a>
       juice company in the northern industrial suburb of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/San_Crist%C3%B3bal_Ecatepec" title="San Cristóbal Ecatepec">
        Ecatepec
       </a>
       . It is said to have the largest private contemporary art collection in
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">
        Latin America
       </a>
       and hosts pieces from its permanent collection as well as traveling exhibits by leading contemporary artists. The new
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museo_J%C3%BAmex" title="Museo Júmex">
        Museo Júmex
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Nuevo_Polanco" title="Nuevo Polanco">
        Nuevo Polanco
       </a>
       was slated to open in November 2013. The Museo de San Ildefonso, housed in the Antiguo Colegio de San Ildefonso in Mexico City's historic downtown district is a 17th-century colonnaded palace housing an art museum that regularly hosts world-class exhibits of Mexican and international art. Recent exhibits have included those on
       <a href="/wiki/David_LaChapelle" title="David LaChapelle">
        David LaChapelle
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Antony_Gormley" title="Antony Gormley">
        Antony Gormley
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Ron_Mueck" title="Ron Mueck">
        Ron Mueck
       </a>
       . The National Museum of Art (Museo Nacional de Arte) is also located in a former palace in the historic center. It houses a large collection of pieces by all major Mexican artists of the last 400 years and also hosts visiting exhibits.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hochob_Campeche_-_Rekonstruktion_des_Tempels.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Hochob_Campeche_-_Rekonstruktion_des_Tempels.jpg/220px-Hochob_Campeche_-_Rekonstruktion_des_Tempels.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Hochob_Campeche_-_Rekonstruktion_des_Tempels.jpg/330px-Hochob_Campeche_-_Rekonstruktion_des_Tempels.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Hochob_Campeche_-_Rekonstruktion_des_Tempels.jpg/440px-Hochob_Campeche_-_Rekonstruktion_des_Tempels.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hochob_Campeche_-_Rekonstruktion_des_Tempels.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Reconstruction of the entrance to the Hochob temple in the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Anthropology" title="National Museum of Anthropology">
          National Museum of Anthropology
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Jack_Kerouac" title="Jack Kerouac">
        Jack Kerouac
       </a>
       , the noted American author, spent extended periods of time in the city, and wrote his masterpiece volume of poetry
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Blues" title="Mexico City Blues">
         Mexico City Blues
        </a>
       </i>
       here. Another American author,
       <a href="/wiki/William_S._Burroughs" title="William S. Burroughs">
        William S. Burroughs
       </a>
       , also lived in the
       <a href="/wiki/Colonia_Roma" title="Colonia Roma">
        Colonia Roma
       </a>
       neighborhood of the city for some time. It was here that he accidentally shot his wife.
      </p>
      <p>
       Most of Mexico City's more than 150 museums can be visited from Tuesday to Sunday from 10 am to 5 pm, although some of them have extended schedules, such as the Museum of Anthropology and History, which is open to 7 pm. In addition to this, entrance to most museums are free on Sunday. In some cases a modest fee may be charged.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
        <a href="#cite_note-135">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Another major addition to the city's museum scene is the
