       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Museum_of_Remembrance_and_Tolerance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Museum of Remembrance and Tolerance (page does not exist)">
        Museum of Remembrance and Tolerance
       </a>
       (Museo de la Memoria y Tolerancia), inaugurated in early 2011. The brainchild of two young Mexican women as a Holocaust museum, the idea morphed into a unique museum dedicated to showcasing all major historical events of discrimination and genocide. Permanent exhibits include those on the Holocaust and other large-scale atrocities. It also houses temporary exhibits; one on
       <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">
        Tibet
       </a>
       was inaugurated by the
       <a href="/wiki/Dalai_Lama" title="Dalai Lama">
        Dalai Lama
       </a>
       in September 2011.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span id="Music.2C_theater_and_entertainment">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Music,_theater_and_entertainment">
        Music, theater and entertainment
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Music, theater and entertainment">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Teatro_de_la_Ciudad_de_Mexico.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="768" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Teatro_de_la_Ciudad_de_Mexico.jpg/220px-Teatro_de_la_Ciudad_de_Mexico.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Teatro_de_la_Ciudad_de_Mexico.jpg/330px-Teatro_de_la_Ciudad_de_Mexico.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Teatro_de_la_Ciudad_de_Mexico.jpg/440px-Teatro_de_la_Ciudad_de_Mexico.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Teatro_de_la_Ciudad_de_Mexico.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The City Theatre
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ACMX16.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/ACMX16.JPG/220px-ACMX16.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/ACMX16.JPG/330px-ACMX16.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/ACMX16.JPG/440px-ACMX16.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ACMX16.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Arena" title="Mexico City Arena">
          Mexico City Arena
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Mexico City is home to a number of orchestras offering season programs. These include the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexico_City_Philharmonic" title="Mexico City Philharmonic">
        Mexico City Philharmonic
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
        <a href="#cite_note-136">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which performs at the Sala Ollin Yoliztli; the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Symphony_Orchestra_(Mexico)" title="National Symphony Orchestra (Mexico)">
        National Symphony Orchestra
       </a>
       , whose home base is the
       <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Bellas_Artes" title="Palacio de Bellas Artes">
        Palacio de Bellas Artes
       </a>
       (Palace of the
       <a href="/wiki/Fine_art" title="Fine art">
        Fine Arts
       </a>
       ), a masterpiece of
       <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">
        art nouveau
       </a>
       and art decó styles; the
       <a href="/wiki/Orchestra" title="Orchestra">
        Philharmonic Orchestra
       </a>
       of the National Autonomous University of Mexico (
       <a href="/wiki/OFUNAM" title="OFUNAM">
        OFUNAM
       </a>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Miner%C3%ADa_Symphony_Orchestra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Minería Symphony Orchestra (page does not exist)">
        Minería Symphony Orchestra
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
        <a href="#cite_note-138">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
       both of which perform at the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Sala_Nezahualc%C3%B3yotl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Sala Nezahualcóyotl (page does not exist)">
        Sala Nezahualcóyotl
       </a>
       , which was the first wrap-around concert hall of the world's western hemisphere when inaugurated in 1976. There are also many smaller ensembles that enrich the city's musical scene, including the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Carlos_Ch%C3%A1vez_Youth_Symphony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Carlos Chávez Youth Symphony (page does not exist)">
        Carlos Chávez Youth Symphony
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Cuarteto_Latinoamericano" title="Cuarteto Latinoamericano">
        Cuarteto Latinoamericano
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_World_Symphony_Orchestra" title="New World Symphony Orchestra">
        New World Orchestra
       </a>
       (Orquesta del Nuevo Mundo), the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=National_Polytechnical_Symphony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="National Polytechnical Symphony (page does not exist)">
        National Polytechnical Symphony
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Bellas_Artes_Chamber_Orchestra&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Bellas Artes Chamber Orchestra (page does not exist)">
        Bellas Artes Chamber Orchestra
       </a>
       (Orquesta de Cámara de Bellas Artes).
      </p>
      <p>
       The city is also a leading center of
       <a href="/wiki/Popular_culture" title="Popular culture">
        popular culture
       </a>
       and music. There are a multitude of venues hosting Spanish and foreign-language performers. These include the 10,000-seat
       <a href="/wiki/National_Auditorium" title="National Auditorium">
        National Auditorium
       </a>
       that regularly schedules the Spanish and English-language pop and rock artists, as well as many of the world's leading
       <a href="/wiki/Performing_arts" title="Performing arts">
        performing arts
       </a>
       ensembles, the auditorium also broadcasts
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Opera" title="Grand Opera">
        Grand Opera
       </a>
       performances from New York's
       <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Opera" title="Metropolitan Opera">
        Metropolitan Opera
       </a>
       on giant, high definition screens. In 2007 National Auditorium was selected world's best venue by multiple genre media.
      </p>
      <p>
       Other popular sites for pop-artist performances include the 3,000-seat
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Teatro_Metropolitan" title="Teatro Metropolitan">
        Teatro Metropolitan
       </a>
       , the 15,000-seat
       <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_los_Deportes" title="Palacio de los Deportes">
        Palacio de los Deportes
       </a>
       , and the larger 50,000-seat
       <a href="/wiki/Foro_Sol" title="Foro Sol">
        Foro Sol
       </a>
       Stadium, where popular international artists perform on a regular basis. The
       <a href="/wiki/Cirque_du_Soleil" title="Cirque du Soleil">
        Cirque du Soleil
       </a>
       has held several seasons at the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Carpa_Santa_Fe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Carpa Santa Fe (page does not exist)">
        Carpa Santa Fe
       </a>
       , in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Santa_Fe_(Mexico_City)" title="Santa Fe (Mexico City)">
        Santa Fe
       </a>
       district in the western part of the city. There are numerous venues for smaller musical ensembles and solo performers. These include the
       <a href="/wiki/Hard_Rock_Live" title="Hard Rock Live">
        Hard Rock Live
       </a>
       , Bataclán, Foro Scotiabank, Lunario, Circo Volador and Voilá Acoustique. Recent additions include the 20,000-seat Arena Ciudad de México, the 3,000-seat Pepsi Center World Trade Center, and the 2,500-seat Auditorio Blackberry.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Centro Nacional de las Artes (
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=National_Center_for_the_Arts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="National Center for the Arts (page does not exist)">
        National Center for the Arts
       </a>
       has several venues for music, theatre, dance. UNAM's main campus, also in the southern part of the city, is home to the Centro Cultural Universitario (the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=University_Culture_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="University Culture Center (page does not exist)">
        University Culture Center
       </a>
       ) (CCU). The CCU also houses the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Mexico" title="National Library of Mexico">
        National Library
       </a>
       , the interactive
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Universum,_Museo_de_las_Ciencias&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Universum, Museo de las Ciencias (page does not exist)">
        Universum, Museo de las Ciencias
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
        <a href="#cite_note-139">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the Sala Nezahualcóyotl concert hall, several theatres and cinemas, and the new University Museum of Contemporary Art (MUAC).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
        <a href="#cite_note-140">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A branch of the National University's CCU cultural center was inaugurated in 2007 in the facilities of the former
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_minister" title="Foreign minister">
        Ministry of Foreign Affairs
       </a>
       , known as Tlatelolco, in north-central Mexico City.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Vasconcelos_Library" title="José Vasconcelos Library">
        José Vasconcelos Library
       </a>
       , a national library, is located on the grounds of the former
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buenavista,_Mexico_State" title="Buenavista, Mexico State">
        Buenavista
       </a>
       railroad station in the northern part of the city.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Papalote_children%27s_museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Papalote children's museum (page does not exist)">
         Papalote children's museum
        </a>
       </i>
       , which houses the world's largest dome screen, is located in the wooded park of
       <a href="/wiki/Chapultepec" title="Chapultepec">
        Chapultepec
       </a>
       , near the
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Museo_Tecnol%C3%B3gico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Museo Tecnológico (page does not exist)">
         Museo Tecnológico
        </a>
       </i>
       , and
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_Feria_de_Chapultepec_M%C3%A1gico" title="La Feria de Chapultepec Mágico">
         La Feria
        </a>
       </i>
       <a href="/wiki/Amusement_park" title="Amusement park">
        amusement park
       </a>
       . The theme park
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Six_Flags_M%C3%A9xico" title="Six Flags México">
         Six Flags México
        </a>
       </i>
       (the largest amusement park in Latin America) is located in the
       <a href="/wiki/Ajusco" title="Ajusco">
        Ajusco
       </a>
       neighborhood, in Tlalpan borough, southern Mexico City. During the winter, the main square of the
       <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%B3calo" title="Zócalo">
        Zócalo
       </a>
       is transformed into a gigantic
       <a href="/wiki/Ice_rink" title="Ice rink">
        ice skating rink
       </a>
       , which is said to be the largest in the world behind that of Moscow's
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Square" title="Red Square">
        Red Square
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The Cineteca Nacional (the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Mexican_Film_Library&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Mexican Film Library (page does not exist)">
        Mexican Film Library
       </a>
       ), near the Coyoacán suburb, shows a variety of films, and stages many film festivals, including the annual
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Muestra_Internacional_de_Cine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Muestra Internacional de Cine (page does not exist)">
        International Showcase
       </a>
       , and many smaller ones ranging from Scandinavian and Uruguayan cinema, to Jewish and LGBT-themed films.
       <a href="/wiki/Cin%C3%A9polis" title="Cinépolis">
        Cinépolis
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Cinemex" title="Cinemex">
        Cinemex
       </a>
       , the two biggest film
       <a href="/wiki/Chain_store" title="Chain store">
        business chains
       </a>
       , also have several film festivals throughout the year, with both national and international movies. Mexico City tops the world in number of
       <a href="/wiki/IMAX" title="IMAX">
        IMAX
       </a>
       theatres,
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2008)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       providing residents and visitors access to films ranging from documentaries to popular blockbusters on these especially large, dramatic screens.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
        Cuisine
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Cuisine">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Mexico City offers a variety of cuisines. Restaurants specializing in the regional cuisines of Mexico's 31 states are available in the city. Also available are an array of international cuisines, including
       <a href="/wiki/Canadian_cuisine" title="Canadian cuisine">
        Canadian
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
        <a href="#cite_note-141">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/French_cuisine" title="French cuisine">
        French
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">
        Italian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Croatian_cuisine" title="Croatian cuisine">
        Croatian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_cuisine" title="Spanish cuisine">
        Spanish
       </a>
       (including many regional variations),
       <a href="/wiki/Jewish_cuisine" title="Jewish cuisine">
        Jewish
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_cuisine" title="Lebanese cuisine">
        Lebanese
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Chinese_cuisine" title="Chinese cuisine">
        Chinese
       </a>
       (again with regional variations),
       <a href="/wiki/Indian_cuisine" title="Indian cuisine">
        Indian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Japanese_cuisine" title="Japanese cuisine">
        Japanese
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Korean_cuisine" title="Korean cuisine">
        Korean
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Thai_cuisine" title="Thai cuisine">
        Thai
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_cuisine" title="Vietnamese cuisine">
        Vietnamese
       </a>
       , and fellow
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_cuisine" title="Latin American cuisine">
        Latin American cuisines
       </a>
       such as
       <a href="/wiki/Argentine_cuisine" title="Argentine cuisine">
        Argentine
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Brazilian_cuisine" title="Brazilian cuisine">
        Brazilian
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Peruvian_cuisine" title="Peruvian cuisine">
        Peruvian
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Haute_cuisine" title="Haute cuisine">
        Haute
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fusion_cuisine" title="Fusion cuisine">
        fusion
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Kashrut" title="Kashrut">
        kosher
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian_cuisine" title="Vegetarian cuisine">
        vegetarian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Veganism" title="Veganism">
        vegan
       </a>
       cuisines are also available, as are restaurants solely based on the concepts of
       <a href="/wiki/Local_food" title="Local food">
        local food
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Slow_Food" title="Slow Food">
        slow Food
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Mexico City is known for having some of the freshest fish and seafood in Mexico's interior.
       <a href="/wiki/La_Nueva_Viga_Market" title="La Nueva Viga Market">
        La Nueva Viga Market
       </a>
       is the second largest seafood market in the world after the
       <a href="/wiki/Tsukiji_fish_market" title="Tsukiji fish market">
        Tsukiji fish market
       </a>
       in Japan.
      </p>
      <p>
       The city also has several branches of renowned international restaurants and chefs. These include Paris' Au Pied de Cochon and
       <a href="/wiki/Brasserie_Lipp" title="Brasserie Lipp">
        Brasserie Lipp
       </a>
       , Philippe (by Philippe Chow); Nobu, Morimoto; Pámpano, owned by Mexican-raised opera legend
       <a href="/wiki/Pl%C3%A1cido_Domingo" title="Plácido Domingo">
        Plácido Domingo
       </a>
       . There are branches of the exclusive Japanese restaurant
       <a href="/wiki/Suntory" title="Suntory">
        Suntory
       </a>
       , Rome's famed Alfredo, as well as New York steakhouses
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Morton%27s_Restaurant_Group" title="Morton's Restaurant Group">
        Morton's
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/The_Palm_(restaurant)" title="The Palm (restaurant)">
        The Palm
       </a>
       , and Monte Carlo's BeefBar. Three of the most famous Lima-based
       <a href="/wiki/Haute_cuisine" title="Haute cuisine">
        Haute
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Peruvian_cuisine" title="Peruvian cuisine">
        Peruvian
       </a>
       restaurants, La Mar, Segundo Muelle and Astrid y Gastón have locations in Mexico City.
      </p>
      <p>
       For the 2014 list of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Restaurant_(magazine)_Top_50" title="Restaurant (magazine) Top 50">
        World's 50 Best Restaurants
       </a>
       as named by the British magazine
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Restaurant_(magazine)" title="Restaurant (magazine)">
         Restaurant
        </a>
       </i>
       , Mexico City ranked with the Mexican avant-garde restaurant
       <a href="/wiki/Pujol_(restaurant)" title="Pujol (restaurant)">
        Pujol
       </a>
       (owned by Mexican chef Enrique Olvera) at 20th best. Also notable is the Basque-Mexican fusion restaurant
       <a href="/wiki/Biko_(restaurant)" title="Biko (restaurant)">
        Biko
       </a>
       (run and co-owned by Bruno Oteiza and Mikel Alonso), which placed outside the list at 59th, but in previous years has ranked within the top 50.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014_awards_142-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-2014_awards-142">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Mexico's award-winning
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_wine" title="Mexican wine">
        wines
       </a>
       are offered at many restaurants, and the city offers unique experiences for tasting the regional spirits, with broad selections of
       <a href="/wiki/Tequila" title="Tequila">
        tequila
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Mezcal" title="Mezcal">
        mezcal
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       At the other end of the scale are working class
       <a href="/wiki/Pulque" title="Pulque">
        pulque
       </a>
       bars known as
       <i>
        pulquerías
       </i>
       , a challenge for tourists to locate and experience.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
        Sports
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Sports">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <tr>
        <th>

       </tr>

        </td>

         </a>
        </td>

       </tr>
       <tr>

         </a>
        </td>

         </a>
        </td>

         <a href="/wiki/Liga_MX" title="Liga MX">

         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Diablos_Rojos_del_M%C3%A9xico" title="Diablos Rojos del México">
          Diablos Rojos del México
         </a>
        </td>
        <td>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fray_Nano_Stadium" title="Fray Nano Stadium">
          Fray Nano Stadium
         </a>
        </td>

         <a href="/wiki/Mexican_League" title="Mexican League">
          Mexican League
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Estadio_Azteca_07a.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Estadio_Azteca_07a.jpg/220px-Estadio_Azteca_07a.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Estadio_Azteca_07a.jpg/330px-Estadio_Azteca_07a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Estadio_Azteca_07a.jpg/440px-Estadio_Azteca_07a.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Estadio_Azteca_07a.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Azteca_Stadium" title="Azteca Stadium">
          Azteca Stadium
         </a>
         , the
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_stadiums_by_capacity" title="List of stadiums by capacity">
          12th largest
         </a>
         stadium in the world
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
        Association football
       </a>
       is the country's most popular and most
       <a href="/wiki/Broadcasting_of_sports_events" title="Broadcasting of sports events">
        televised franchised sport
       </a>
       . Its important venues in Mexico City include the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Azteca_Stadium" title="Azteca Stadium">
        Azteca Stadium
       </a>
       , home to the
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team" title="Mexico national football team">
        Mexico national football team
       </a>
       and giants
       <a href="/wiki/Club_Am%C3%A9rica" title="Club América">
        América
       </a>
       , which can seat 91,653 fans, making it the biggest stadium in Latin America. The
       <a href="/wiki/Estadio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Universitario" title="Estadio Olímpico Universitario">
        Olympic Stadium
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Universitaria" title="Ciudad Universitaria">
        Ciudad Universitaria
       </a>
       is home to the football club giants
       <a href="/wiki/Club_Universidad_Nacional" title="Club Universidad Nacional">
        Universidad Nacional
       </a>
       , with a
       <a href="/wiki/Seating_capacity" title="Seating capacity">
        seating capacity
       </a>
       of over 52,000. The
       <a href="/wiki/Estadio_Azul" title="Estadio Azul">
        Estadio Azul
       </a>
       , which seats 33,042 fans, is near the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_Mexico_City" title="World Trade Center Mexico City">
        World Trade Center Mexico City
       </a>
       in the Nochebuena
       <a href="/wiki/Colonia_(Mexico)" title="Colonia (Mexico)">
        neighborhood
       </a>
       , and is home to the giants
       <a href="/wiki/Cruz_Azul" title="Cruz Azul">
        Cruz Azul
       </a>
       . The three teams are based in Mexico City and play in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Primera_Divisi%C3%B3n_de_M%C3%A9xico" title="Primera División de México">
        First Division
       </a>
       ; they are also part, with Guadalajara-based giants
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Club_Deportivo_Guadalajara" title="Club Deportivo Guadalajara">
        Club Deportivo Guadalajara
       </a>
       , of Mexico's traditional "Big Four" (though recent years have tended to erode the teams' leading status at least in standings). The country hosted the
       <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">
        FIFA World Cup
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1970 FIFA World Cup">
        1970
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1986 FIFA World Cup">
        1986
       </a>
       , and Azteca Stadium is the first stadium in World Cup history to host the final twice.
      </p>
      <p>
       Mexico City is the first Latin American city to host the Olympic Games, having held the
       <a href="/wiki/1968_Summer_Olympics" title="1968 Summer Olympics">
        Summer Olympics
       </a>
       in 1968, winning bids against
       <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">
        Buenos Aires
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lyon" title="Lyon">
        Lyon
       </a>
       and Detroit. The city hosted the 1955 and 1975
       <a href="/wiki/Pan_American_Games" title="Pan American Games">
        Pan American Games
       </a>
       , the last after Santiago and São Paulo withdrew. The
       <a href="/wiki/ICF_Canoe_Sprint_World_Championships" title="ICF Canoe Sprint World Championships">
        ICF Flatwater Racing World Championships
       </a>
       were hosted here in 1974 and 1994.
       <a href="/wiki/Lucha_libre" title="Lucha libre">
        Lucha libre
       </a>
       is a Mexican style of wrestling, and is one of the more popular sports throughout the country. The main venues in the city are
       <a href="/wiki/Arena_M%C3%A9xico" title="Arena México">
        Arena México
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Arena_Coliseo" title="Arena Coliseo">
        Arena Coliseo
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Estadio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Universitario_2.jpeg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="814" data-file-width="1088" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Estadio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Universitario_2.jpeg/220px-Estadio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Universitario_2.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Estadio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Universitario_2.jpeg/330px-Estadio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Universitario_2.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Estadio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Universitario_2.jpeg/440px-Estadio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Universitario_2.jpeg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Estadio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Universitario_2.jpeg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Estadio_Ol%C3%ADmpico_Universitario" title="Estadio Olímpico Universitario">
          Estadio Olímpico Universitario
         </a>
         , considered as the most important building in modern America, by American architect
         <a href="/wiki/Frank_Lloyd_Wright" title="Frank Lloyd Wright">
          Frank Lloyd Wright
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Aut%C3%B3dromo_Hermanos_Rodr%C3%ADguez" title="Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez">
        Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez
       </a>
       is the main venue for motorsport, and hosts the Formula 1
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Grand_Prix" title="Mexican Grand Prix">
        Mexican Grand Prix
       </a>
       since its return to the sport in 2015, the event being held in the past from 1962 to 1970, and again from 1986 to 1992. From 1980 to 1981 and again from 2002 to 2007, the circuit hosted the
       <a href="/wiki/Champ_Car" title="Champ Car">
        Champ Car
       </a>
       World Series
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gran_Premio_de_M%C3%A9xico" title="Gran Premio de México">
        Gran Premio de México
       </a>
       . Beginning in 2005, the
       <a href="/wiki/NASCAR" title="NASCAR">
        NASCAR
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nationwide_Series" title="Nationwide Series">
        Nationwide Series
       </a>
       ran the
       <a href="/wiki/Corona_M%C3%A9xico_200" title="Corona México 200">
        Telcel-Motorola México 200
       </a>
       . 2005 also marked the first running of the Mexico City 250 by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_American_Road_Racing_Association" title="Grand American Road Racing Association">
        Grand-Am
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Rolex_Sports_Car_Series" title="Rolex Sports Car Series">
        Rolex Sports Car Series
       </a>
       . Both races were removed from their series' schedules for 2009.
      </p>
      <p>
       Baseball is another sport played professionally in the city. Mexico City is currently home of the
       <a href="/wiki/Diablos_Rojos_del_M%C3%A9xico" title="Diablos Rojos del México">
        Mexico City Red Devils
       </a>
       of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexican_League_(baseball)" title="Mexican League (baseball)">
        Mexican League
       </a>
       , which is considered a Triple-A league by Major League Baseball. The Devils play their home games at the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fray_Nano_Stadium" title="Fray Nano Stadium">
        Fray Nano Stadium
       </a>
       , a temporary venue until their new ballpark is completed. Mexico City has some 10 Little Leagues for young baseball players.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2005, Mexico City became the first city to host an
       <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">
        NFL
       </a>
       regular season game outside of the United States, at the
       <a href="/wiki/Estadio_Azteca" title="Estadio Azteca">
        Azteca Stadium
       </a>
       . The crowd of 103,467 people attending this game was the largest ever for a regular season game in NFL history until 2009.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
        <a href="#cite_note-143">
         [143]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The city has also hosted several
       <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">
        NBA
       </a>
       pre-season games and has hosted international basketball's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_Americas_Championship" title="FIBA Americas Championship">
        FIBA Americas Championship
       </a>
       , along with north-of-the-border Major League Baseball exhibition games at
       <a href="/wiki/Foro_Sol" title="Foro Sol">
        Foro Sol
       </a>
       . In 2017, NBA commissioner
       <a href="/wiki/Adam_Silver" title="Adam Silver">
        Adam Silver
       </a>
       expressed interest in placing an
       <a href="/wiki/NBA_G_League" title="NBA G League">
        NBA G League
       </a>
       expansion team in Mexico City as early as 2018.
      </p>
      <p>
       Other sports facilities in Mexico City are the
       <a href="/wiki/Palacio_de_los_Deportes" title="Palacio de los Deportes">
        Palacio de los Deportes
       </a>
       indoor arena,
       <a href="/wiki/Alberca_Ol%C3%ADmpica_Francisco_M%C3%A1rquez" title="Alberca Olímpica Francisco Márquez">
        Francisco Márquez Olympic Swimming Pool
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Hip%C3%B3dromo_de_las_Am%C3%A9ricas" title="Hipódromo de las Américas">
        Hipódromo de Las Américas
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Agustin_Melgar_Olympic_Velodrome" title="Agustin Melgar Olympic Velodrome">
        Agustin Melgar Olympic Velodrome
       </a>
       , and venues for equestrianism and horse racing, ice hockey,
       <a href="/wiki/Rugby_football" title="Rugby football">
        rugby
       </a>
       , American-style football, baseball, and basketball.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Bullfighting" title="Bullfighting">
        Bullfighting
       </a>
       takes place every Sunday during bullfighting season at the 50,000-seat
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plaza_M%C3%A9xico" title="Plaza México">
        Plaza México
       </a>
       , the world's largest bullring.
      </p>
      <p>
       Mexico City's
       <a href="/wiki/Golf_course" title="Golf course">
        golf courses
       </a>
       have hosted Women's
       <a href="/wiki/LPGA" title="LPGA">
        LPGA
       </a>
       action, and two
       <a href="/wiki/World_Cup_(men%27s_golf)" title="World Cup (men's golf)">
        Men's Golf World Cups
       </a>
       . Courses throughout the city are available as private as well as public venues.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
        Education
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Education">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em">
       <caption class="fn org">
        Ciudad Universitaria
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UNAM_library.jpg">
          <img alt="UNAM library.jpg" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="1024" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/UNAM_library.jpg/220px-UNAM_library.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/UNAM_library.jpg/330px-UNAM_library.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/UNAM_library.jpg/440px-UNAM_library.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
         <div>
          <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">
           National Autonomous University of Mexico
          </a>
          , Mexico's biggest Public Institution
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="padding-right:0.65em;">
         <div style="padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">
          Parent institution
         </div>
        </th>

         <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">
          UNAM
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="padding-right:0.65em;">
         Location
        </th>
        <td class="adr">
         <span class="locality">
          Ciudad Universitaria
         </span>
         ,
         <span class="country-name">
          Mexico
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedrow">
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
         <div style="border:4px solid #FFE153; line-height: 1.5; text-align: center;">
          <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">
           UNESCO World Heritage Site
          </a>
         </div>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedrow">
        <th scope="row">
         Official name
        </th>
        <td>
         Central University City Campus of the
         <i>
          Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México
         </i>
         (UNAM)
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedrow">
        <th scope="row">
         Type

        </td>

         <small>
          (31st
          <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Committee" title="World Heritage Committee">
           session
          </a>
          )
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedrow">
        <th scope="row">
         Reference no.
        </th>
        <td>
         <a class="external text" href="http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1250" rel="nofollow">
          1250
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedrow">
        <th scope="row">
         State Party
        </th>
        <td>
         Mexico
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr class="mergedrow">
        <th scope="row">
         Region
        </th>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_North_America" title="List of World Heritage Sites in North America">
          Latin America and the Caribbean
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr style="display:none">
        <th colspan="2">
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2">
        </th>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/National_Autonomous_University_of_Mexico" title="National Autonomous University of Mexico">
        National Autonomous University of Mexico
       </a>
       (UNAM), located in Mexico City, is the largest university on the continent, with more than 300,000 students from all backgrounds. Three
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates" title="List of Nobel laureates">
        Nobel laureates
       </a>
       , several Mexican entrepreneurs and most of Mexico's modern-day presidents are among its former students. UNAM conducts 50% of Mexico's
       <a href="/wiki/Scientific_method" title="Scientific method">
        scientific research
       </a>
       and has presence all across the country with satellite campuses, observatories and research centres. UNAM ranked 74th in the Top 200 World
       <a href="/wiki/College_and_university_rankings" title="College and university rankings">
        University Ranking
       </a>
       published by
       <a href="/wiki/Times_Higher_Education" title="Times Higher Education">
        Times Higher Education
       </a>
       (then called Times Higher Education Supplement) in 2006,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
        <a href="#cite_note-144">
         [144]
        </a>
       </sup>
       making it the highest ranked Spanish-speaking university in the world. The sprawling main campus of the university, known as
       <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Universitaria" title="Ciudad Universitaria">
        Ciudad Universitaria
       </a>
       , was named a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 2007.
      </p>
      <p>
       The second largest higher-education institution is the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Polytechnic_Institute" title="National Polytechnic Institute">
        National Polytechnic Institute
       </a>
       (IPN), which includes among many other relevant centers the
       <a href="/wiki/CINVESTAV" title="CINVESTAV">
        Centro de Investigación y de Estudios Avanzados
       </a>
       (Cinvestav), where varied high-level scientific and technological research is done. Other major higher-education institutions in the city include the
       <a href="/wiki/Universidad_Aut%C3%B3noma_Metropolitana" title="Universidad Autónoma Metropolitana">
        Metropolitan Autonomous University
       </a>
       (UAM), the
       <a href="/wiki/National_School_of_Anthropology_and_History" title="National School of Anthropology and History">
        National School of Anthropology and History
       </a>
       (ENAH), the
       <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Tecnol%C3%B3gico_Aut%C3%B3nomo_de_M%C3%A9xico" title="Instituto Tecnológico Autónomo de México">
        Instituto Tecnológico Autónomo de México
       </a>
       (ITAM), the
       <a href="/wiki/Monterrey_Institute_of_Technology_and_Higher_Education" title="Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education">
        Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education
       </a>
       (3 campuses), the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universidad_Panamericana_Sede_M%C3%A9xico" title="Universidad Panamericana Sede México">
        Universidad Panamericana
       </a>
       (UP), the
       <a href="/wiki/Universidad_La_Salle" title="Universidad La Salle">
        Universidad La Salle
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Universidad_del_Valle_de_M%C3%A9xico" title="Universidad del Valle de México">
        Universidad del Valle de Mexico
       </a>
       (UVM), the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anahuac_Universities_Network" title="Anahuac Universities Network">
        Universidad Anáhuac
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Simon_Bolivar_University_(Mexico)" title="Simon Bolivar University (Mexico)">
        Simon Bolivar University
       </a>
       (USB), the
       <a href="/wiki/Alliant_International_University" title="Alliant International University">
        Alliant International University
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Universidad_Iberoamericana" title="Universidad Iberoamericana">
        Universidad Iberoamericana
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/El_Colegio_de_M%C3%A9xico" title="El Colegio de México">
        El Colegio de México
       </a>
       (Colmex),
       <a href="/wiki/Escuela_Libre_de_Derecho" title="Escuela Libre de Derecho">
        Escuela Libre de Derecho
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Centro_de_Investigaci%C3%B3n_y_Docencia_Econ%C3%B3micas" title="Centro de Investigación y Docencia Económicas">
        Centro de Investigación y Docencia Económica
       </a>
       , (CIDE). In addition, the prestigious
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_California" title="University of California">
        University of California
       </a>
       maintains a campus known as "Casa de California" in the city.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
        <a href="#cite_note-145">
         [145]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Universidad_Tecnol%C3%B3gica_de_M%C3%A9xico" title="Universidad Tecnológica de México">
        Universidad Tecnológica de México
       </a>
       is also in Mexico City.
      </p>
      <p>
       Unlike those of Mexican states' schools, curricula of Mexico City's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_school_(government_funded)" title="Public school (government funded)">
        public schools
       </a>
       is managed by the federal
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_Public_Education" title="Secretariat of Public Education">
        Secretary of Public Education
       </a>
       . The whole funding is allocated by the government of Mexico City (in some specific cases, such as
       <a href="/wiki/El_Colegio_de_M%C3%A9xico" title="El Colegio de México">
        El Colegio de México
       </a>
       , funding comes from both the city's government and other public and private national and international entities).
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2008)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
       The city's public high school system is the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Instituto_de_Educaci%C3%B3n_Media_Superior_del_Distrito_Federal" title="Instituto de Educación Media Superior del Distrito Federal">
         Instituto de Educación Media Superior del Distrito Federal
        </a>
       </i>
       (IEMS-DF).
      </p>
      <p>
       A special case is that of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colegio_Nacional_(Mexico)" title="Colegio Nacional (Mexico)">
        El Colegio Nacional
       </a>
       , created during the district's governmental period of
       <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Alem%C3%A1n_Vald%C3%A9s" title="Miguel Alemán Valdés">
        Miguel Alemán Valdés
       </a>
       to have, in Mexico, an institution similar to the
       <a href="/wiki/Coll%C3%A8ge_de_France" title="Collège de France">
        College of France
       </a>
       . The select and privileged group of Mexican scientists and artists belonging to this institution—membership is for life—include, among many,
       <a href="/wiki/Mario_Lavista" title="Mario Lavista">
        Mario Lavista
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Ruy_P%C3%A9rez_Tamayo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Ruy Pérez Tamayo (page does not exist)">
        Ruy Pérez Tamayo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Emilio_Pacheco" title="José Emilio Pacheco">
        José Emilio Pacheco
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Marcos_Moshinsky" title="Marcos Moshinsky">
        Marcos Moshinsky
       </a>
       (d.2009),
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Guillermo_Sober%C3%B3n_Acevedo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Guillermo Soberón Acevedo (page does not exist)">
        Guillermo Soberón Acevedo
       </a>
       . Members are obligated to publicly disclose their works through conferences and public events such as concerts and recitals.
      </p>
      <p>
       Among its many public and private schools (K–13), the city offers
       <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">
        multi-cultural
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Multilingualism" title="Multilingualism">
        multi-lingual
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/International_school" title="International school">
        international schools
       </a>
       attended by Mexican and
       <a href="/wiki/International_student" title="International student">
        foreign students
       </a>
       . Best known are the
       <a href="/wiki/Colegio_Alem%C3%A1n_Alexander_von_Humboldt_(Mexico_City)" title="Colegio Alemán Alexander von Humboldt (Mexico City)">
        Colegio Alemán
       </a>
       (German school with three main campuses), the
       <a href="/wiki/Liceo_Mexicano_Japon%C3%A9s" title="Liceo Mexicano Japonés">
        Liceo Mexicano Japonés
       </a>
       (Japanese), the Centro Cultural Coreano en México (Korean), the
       <a href="/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Franco-Mexicain" title="Lycée Franco-Mexicain">
        Lycée Franco-Mexicain
       </a>
       (French), the
       <a href="/wiki/ASF_Mexico" title="ASF Mexico">
        American School
       </a>
       , The
       <a href="/wiki/Westhill_Institute" title="Westhill Institute">
        Westhill Institute
       </a>
       (American School), the
       <a href="/wiki/Edron_Academy" title="Edron Academy">
        Edron Academy
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Greengates_School" title="Greengates School">
        Greengates School
       </a>
       (British).
      </p>
      <div class="center">
       <table>
        <tr>
         <td valign="top">
          <div class="thumb tright">
           <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">

            </a>
            <div class="thumbcaption">

             </a>
             Private University
            </div>

          <div class="thumb tright">
           <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
            <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Biblioteca_Vasconcelos_-_vista_a_los_jardines_desde_el_primer_piso.jpg">
             <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4928" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Biblioteca_Vasconcelos_-_vista_a_los_jardines_desde_el_primer_piso.jpg/220px-Biblioteca_Vasconcelos_-_vista_a_los_jardines_desde_el_primer_piso.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Biblioteca_Vasconcelos_-_vista_a_los_jardines_desde_el_primer_piso.jpg/330px-Biblioteca_Vasconcelos_-_vista_a_los_jardines_desde_el_primer_piso.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Biblioteca_Vasconcelos_-_vista_a_los_jardines_desde_el_primer_piso.jpg/440px-Biblioteca_Vasconcelos_-_vista_a_los_jardines_desde_el_primer_piso.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
            </a>
            <div class="thumbcaption">
             <div class="magnify">
