              </a>
             </div>
             <a href="/wiki/Biblioteca_Vasconcelos" title="Biblioteca Vasconcelos">
              Biblioteca Vasconcelos
             </a>
            </div>
           </div>
          </div>
         </td>
         <td valign="top">
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
        Media
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Media">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Mexico City is Latin America's leading center for the television, music and film industries. It is also Mexico's most important for the printed media and
       <a href="/wiki/Publishing" title="Publishing">
        book publishing
       </a>
       industries. Dozens of daily newspapers are published, including
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/El_Universal_(Mexico_City)" title="El Universal (Mexico City)">
         El Universal
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Exc%C3%A9lsior" title="Excélsior">
         Excélsior
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Reforma" title="Reforma">
         Reforma
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/La_Jornada" title="La Jornada">
         La Jornada
        </a>
       </i>
       . Other major papers include
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Milenio" title="Milenio">
         Milenio
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cr%C3%B3nica,_Buenos_Aires" title="Crónica, Buenos Aires">
         Crónica
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/El_Economista" title="El Economista">
         El Economista
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/El_Financiero" title="El Financiero">
         El Financiero
        </a>
       </i>
       . Leading magazines include
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Expansi%C3%B3n_(Mexico)" title="Expansión (Mexico)">
         Expansión
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Proceso_(magazine)" title="Proceso (magazine)">
         Proceso
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Poder&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Poder (page does not exist)">
         Poder
        </a>
       </i>
       , as well as dozens of entertainment publications such as
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Vanidades" title="Vanidades">
         Vanidades
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Qui%C3%A9n_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Quién (magazine) (page does not exist)">
         Quién
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Chilango" title="Chilango">
         Chilango
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=TVNotas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="TVNotas (page does not exist)">
         TV Notas
        </a>
       </i>
       , and local editions of
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Vogue_(magazine)" title="Vogue (magazine)">
         Vogue
        </a>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/GQ" title="GQ">
         GQ
        </a>
       </i>
       , and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Architectural_Digest" title="Architectural Digest">
         Architectural Digest
        </a>
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       It is also a leading center of the
       <a href="/wiki/Advertising_industry" title="Advertising industry">
        advertising industry
       </a>
       . Most international ad firms have offices in the city, including Grey,
       <a href="/wiki/J._Walter_Thompson" title="J. Walter Thompson">
        JWT
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Leo_Burnett" title="Leo Burnett">
        Leo Burnett
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Euro_RSCG" title="Euro RSCG">
        Euro RSCG
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/BBDO" title="BBDO">
        BBDO
       </a>
       , Ogilvy,
       <a href="/wiki/Saatchi_%26_Saatchi" title="Saatchi &amp; Saatchi">
        Saatchi &amp; Saatchi
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/McCann_Erickson" title="McCann Erickson">
        McCann Erickson
       </a>
       . Many local firms also compete in the sector, including
       <a href="/wiki/Alazraki" title="Alazraki">
        Alazraki
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Olabuenaga/Chemistri&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Olabuenaga/Chemistri (page does not exist)">
        Olabuenaga/Chemistri
       </a>
       , Terán, Augusto Elías, and Clemente Cámara, among others. There are 60
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_radio_stations_in_Distrito_Federal" title="List of radio stations in Distrito Federal">
        radio stations
       </a>
       operating in the city and many
       <a href="/wiki/Local_community" title="Local community">
        local community
       </a>
       radio transmission networks.
      </p>
      <p>
       The two largest media companies in the Spanish-speaking world,
       <a href="/wiki/Televisa" title="Televisa">
        Televisa
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Azteca_(television)" title="Azteca (television)">
        Azteca
       </a>
       , are headquartered in Mexico City. Other
       <a href="/wiki/Television_channel" title="Television channel">
        local television
       </a>
       channels include:
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/XEW-TDT" title="XEW-TDT">
        XEW
       </a>
       2,
       <a href="/wiki/XHTV-TDT" title="XHTV-TDT">
        XHTV
       </a>
       4,
       <a href="/wiki/XHGC-TDT" title="XHGC-TDT">
        XHGC
       </a>
       5,
       <a href="/wiki/XHIMT-TDT" title="XHIMT-TDT">
        XHIMT
       </a>
       7,
       <a href="/wiki/XEQ-TDT" title="XEQ-TDT">
        XEQ
       </a>
       9,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/XEIPN-TDT" title="XEIPN-TDT">
        XEIPN
       </a>
       11,
       <a href="/wiki/XHDF-TDT" title="XHDF-TDT">
        XHDF
       </a>
       13,
       <a href="/wiki/XHUNAM-TDT" title="XHUNAM-TDT">
        XHUNAM
       </a>
       20,
       <a href="/wiki/XHCDM-TDT" title="XHCDM-TDT">
        XHCDM
       </a>
       21,
       <a href="/wiki/XEIMT-TDT" title="XEIMT-TDT">
        XEIMT
       </a>
       22,
       <a href="/wiki/XHTRES-TDT" title="XHTRES-TDT">
        XHTRES
       </a>
       28,
       <a href="/wiki/XHTVM-TDT" title="XHTVM-TDT">
        XHTVM
       </a>
       40 and
       <a href="/wiki/XHHCU-TDT" title="XHHCU-TDT">
        XHHCU
       </a>
       45.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Shopping">
        Shopping
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Shopping">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Mexico City offers an immense and varied consumer retail market, ranging from basic foods to ultra high-end luxury goods. Consumers may buy in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_fixed_markets_in_Mexico" title="Traditional fixed markets in Mexico">
        fixed indoor markets
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Tianguis" title="Tianguis">
        mobile markets (
        <i>
         tianguis
        </i>
        )
       </a>
       , from
       <a href="/wiki/Street_vendors_in_Mexico_City" title="Street vendors in Mexico City">
        street vendors
       </a>
       , from downtown shops in a street dedicated to a certain type of good, in convenience stores and traditional neighborhood stores, in modern supermarkets, in warehouse and membership stores and the shopping centers that they anchor, in department stores,
       <a href="/wiki/Big-box_store" title="Big-box store">
        big-box stores
       </a>
       and in modern shopping malls.
      </p>
      <p>
       In addition, "
       <a href="/wiki/Tianguis" title="Tianguis">
        tianguis
       </a>
       " or mobile markets set up shop on streets in many neighborhoods, depending on day of week. Sundays see the largest number of these markets.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Traditional_markets">
        Traditional markets
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: Traditional markets">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_fixed_markets_in_Mexico" title="Traditional fixed markets in Mexico">
        Traditional fixed markets in Mexico
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sanborns_DF.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="768" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Sanborns_DF.jpg/220px-Sanborns_DF.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Sanborns_DF.jpg/330px-Sanborns_DF.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Sanborns_DF.jpg/440px-Sanborns_DF.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sanborns_DF.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Multi-storey
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sanborns" title="Sanborns">
          Sanborns
         </a>
         department store with the façade of a 19th-century home being used as an entrance area
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The city's main source of fresh produce is the
       <a href="/wiki/Central_de_Abasto" title="Central de Abasto">
        Central de Abasto
       </a>
       . This in itself is a self-contained mini-city in
       <a href="/wiki/Iztapalapa" title="Iztapalapa">
        Iztapalapa
       </a>
       borough covering an area equivalent to several dozen city blocks. The wholesale market supplies most of the city's "mercados", supermarkets and restaurants, as well as people who come to buy the produce for themselves. Tons of fresh produce are trucked in from all over Mexico every day.
      </p>
      <p>
       The principal fish market is known as
       <a href="/wiki/La_Nueva_Viga_Market" title="La Nueva Viga Market">
        La Nueva Viga
       </a>
       , in the same complex as the Central de Abastos. The world-renowned market of
       <a href="/wiki/Tepito" title="Tepito">
        Tepito
       </a>
       occupies 25 blocks, and sells a variety of products.
      </p>
      <p>
       A staple for consumers in the city is the omnipresent "mercado". Every major neighborhood in the city has its own borough-regulated market, often more than one. These are large well-established facilities offering most basic products, such as fresh produce and meat/poultry, dry goods, tortillerías, and many other services such as locksmiths, herbal medicine, hardware goods, sewing implements; and a multitude of stands offering freshly made, home-style cooking and drinks in the tradition of
       <a href="/wiki/Aguas_frescas" title="Aguas frescas">
        aguas frescas
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Atole" title="Atole">
        atole
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Street_vendors">
        Street vendors
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Street vendors">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Street_vendors_in_Mexico_City" title="Street vendors in Mexico City">
        Street vendors in Mexico City
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Street vendors ply their trade from stalls in the
       <i>
        tianguis
       </i>
       as well as at non-officially controlled concentrations around metro stations and hospitals; at
       <i>
        plazas comerciales
       </i>
       , where vendors of a certain "theme" (e.g. stationery) are housed; originally these were organized to accommodate vendors formerly selling on the street; or simply from improvised stalls on a city sidewalk.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pena_146-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-pena-146">
         [146]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In addition, food and goods are sold from people walking with baskets, pushing carts, from bicycles or the backs of trucks, or simply from a tarp or cloth laid on the ground.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
        <a href="#cite_note-147">
         [147]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the centre of the city informal street vendors are increasingly targeted by laws and prosecution.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mueller_148-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mueller-148">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The weekly
       <a href="/wiki/San_Felipe_de_Jes%C3%BAs_Tianguis" title="San Felipe de Jesús Tianguis">
        San Felipe de Jesús Tianguis
       </a>
       is reported to be the largest in Latin America.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
        <a href="#cite_note-149">
         [149]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Downtown_shopping">
        Downtown shopping
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Downtown shopping">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PalacioHierroOrigStoreCentroDF.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1570" data-file-width="1160" height="298" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/PalacioHierroOrigStoreCentroDF.JPG/220px-PalacioHierroOrigStoreCentroDF.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/PalacioHierroOrigStoreCentroDF.JPG/330px-PalacioHierroOrigStoreCentroDF.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/PalacioHierroOrigStoreCentroDF.JPG/440px-PalacioHierroOrigStoreCentroDF.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PalacioHierroOrigStoreCentroDF.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palacio_de_Hierro" title="Palacio de Hierro">
          Palacio de Hierro
         </a>
         store
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Historic_Center_of_Mexico_City" title="Historic Center of Mexico City">
        Historic Center of Mexico City
       </a>
       is widely known for specialized, often low-cost retailers. Certain blocks or streets are dedicated to shops selling a certain type of merchandise, with areas dedicated to over 40 categories such as home appliances, lamps and electricals, closets and bathrooms, housewares, wedding dresses, jukeboxes, printing, office furniture and safes, books, photography, jewelry, and opticians.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
        <a href="#cite_note-150">
         [150]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The main department stores are also represented downtown.
      </p>
      <p>
       Traditional markets downtown include the
       <a href="/wiki/La_Merced_Market" title="La Merced Market">
        La Merced Market
       </a>
       ; the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mercado_Jamaica,_Mexico_City" title="Mercado Jamaica, Mexico City">
        Mercado de Jamaica
       </a>
       specializes in fresh flowers, the
       <a href="/wiki/Mercado_de_Sonora" title="Mercado de Sonora">
        Mercado de Sonora
       </a>
       in the occult, and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_Lagunilla" title="La Lagunilla">
        La Lagunilla
       </a>
       in furniture.
      </p>
      <p>
       Ethnic shopping areas are located in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Mexico_City" title="Chinatown, Mexico City">
        Chinatown
       </a>
       , downtown along Calle Dolores, but Mexico City's
       <a href="/wiki/Koreatown" title="Koreatown">
        Koreatown
       </a>
       , or
       <a href="/wiki/Peque%C3%B1o_Se%C3%BAl" title="Pequeño Seúl">
        Pequeño Seúl
       </a>
       , is located in the
       <a href="/wiki/Zona_Rosa,_Mexico_City" title="Zona Rosa, Mexico City">
        Zona Rosa
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Supermarkets_and_neighborhood_stores">
        Supermarkets and neighborhood stores
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Supermarkets and neighborhood stores">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Large, modern chain supermarkets,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hypermarkets" title="Hypermarkets">
        hypermarkets
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Warehouse_club" title="Warehouse club">
        warehouse clubs
       </a>
       including
       <a href="/wiki/Soriana" title="Soriana">
        Soriana
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Comercial_Mexicana" title="Comercial Mexicana">
        Comercial Mexicana
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Chedraui" title="Chedraui">
        Chedraui
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bodega_Aurrer%C3%A1" title="Bodega Aurrerá">
        Bodega Aurrerá
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Walmart" title="Walmart">
        Walmart
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Costco" title="Costco">
        Costco
       </a>
       , are located across the city. Many anchor shopping centers that contain smaller shops, services, a
       <a href="/wiki/Food_court" title="Food court">
        food court
       </a>
       and sometimes cinemas.
      </p>
      <p>
       Small "mom-and-pop" corner stores ("abarroterías" or more colloquially as "changarros") abound in all neighborhoods, rich and poor. These are small shops offering basics such as soft drinks, packaged snacks, canned goods and dairy products. Thousands of
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=C-stores&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="C-stores (page does not exist)">
        C-stores
       </a>
       or corner stores, such as
       <a href="/wiki/OXXO" title="OXXO">
        Oxxo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/7-Eleven" title="7-Eleven">
        7-Eleven
       </a>
       and Extra are located throughout the city.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Parks_and_recreation">
        Parks and recreation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: Parks and recreation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chapultepec_Park" title="Chapultepec Park">
        Chapultepec Park
       </a>
       , the city's most iconic public park, has history back to the Aztec emperors who used the area as a retreat. It is south of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polanco_(Mexico)" title="Polanco (Mexico)">
        Polanco
       </a>
       district, and houses the
       <a href="/wiki/Chapultepec_Zoo" title="Chapultepec Zoo">
        city's zoo
       </a>
       , several ponds, seven museums including the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museo_Nacional_de_Antropolog%C3%ADa" title="Museo Nacional de Antropología">
        National Museum of Anthropology
       </a>
       , and the oldest and most traditional amusement park,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_Feria_de_Chapultepec_M%C3%A1gico" title="La Feria de Chapultepec Mágico">
        La Feria de Chapultepec Mágico
       </a>
       , with its vintage Montaña Rusa rollercoaster.
      </p>
      <p>
       Other iconic city parks include the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alameda_Central,_Mexico_City" title="Alameda Central, Mexico City">
        Alameda Central, Mexico City
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Historic_center_of_Mexico_City" title="Historic center of Mexico City">
        historic center
       </a>
       , a city park since colonial times and renovated in 2013;
       <a href="/wiki/Parque_M%C3%A9xico" title="Parque México">
        Parque México
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Parque_Espa%C3%B1a" title="Parque España">
        Parque España
       </a>
       in the hip
       <a href="/wiki/Condesa" title="Condesa">
        Condesa
       </a>
       district;
       <a href="/wiki/Parque_Hundido" title="Parque Hundido">
        Parque Hundido
       </a>
       and
       <i>
        Parque de los Venados
       </i>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Colonia_del_Valle" title="Colonia del Valle">
        Colonia del Valle
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Parque_Lincoln" title="Parque Lincoln">
        Parque Lincoln
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Polanco,_Mexico_City" title="Polanco, Mexico City">
        Polanco
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
        <a href="#cite_note-151">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are many smaller parks throughout the city. Most are small "squares" occupying two or three square blocks amid residential or commercial districts.
      </p>
      <p>
       Several other larger parks such as the Bosque de Tlalpan and
       <a href="/wiki/Viveros_de_Coyoac%C3%A1n" title="Viveros de Coyoacán">
        Viveros de Coyoacán
       </a>
       , and in the east
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Alameda_Oriente&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Alameda Oriente (page does not exist)">
        Alameda Oriente
       </a>
       , offer many recreational activities. Northwest of the city is a large ecological reserve, the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Bosque_de_Arag%C3%B3n&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Bosque de Aragón (page does not exist)">
        Bosque de Aragón
       </a>
       . In the southeast is the
       <a href="/wiki/Xochimilco_Ecological_Park_and_Plant_Market" title="Xochimilco Ecological Park and Plant Market">
        Xochimilco Ecological Park and Plant Market
       </a>
       , a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Heritage_site" title="World Heritage site">
        World Heritage site
       </a>
       . West of
       <a href="/wiki/Santa_Fe,_Mexico_City" title="Santa Fe, Mexico City">
        Santa Fe
       </a>
       district are the pine forests of the
       <a href="/wiki/Desierto_de_los_Leones_National_Park" title="Desierto de los Leones National Park">
        Desierto de los Leones National Park
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Amusement parks include
       <a href="/wiki/Six_Flags_M%C3%A9xico" title="Six Flags México">
        Six Flags México
       </a>
       , in Ajusco neighborhood which is the largest in Latin America. There are numerous seasonal fairs present in the city.
      </p>
      <p>
       Mexico City has three zoos.
       <a href="/wiki/Chapultepec_Zoo" title="Chapultepec Zoo">
        Chapultepec Zoo
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=San_Juan_de_Aragon_Zoo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="San Juan de Aragon Zoo (page does not exist)">
        San Juan de Aragon Zoo
       </a>
       and
       <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Los_Coyotes_Zoo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Los Coyotes Zoo (page does not exist)">
        Los Coyotes Zoo
       </a>
       . Chapultepec Zoo is located in the first section of Chapultepec Park in the Miguel Hidalgo. It was opened in 1924.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
        <a href="#cite_note-152">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Visitors can see about 243 specimens of different species including kangaroos, giant panda, gorillas, caracal, hyena, hippos, jaguar, giraffe, lemur, lion, among others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
        <a href="#cite_note-153">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Zoo San Juan de Aragon is near the San Juan de Aragon Park in the Gustavo A. Madero. In this zoo, opened in 1964,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
        <a href="#cite_note-154">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       there are species that are in danger of extinction such as the jaguar and the Mexican wolf. Other guests are the golden eagle, pronghorn, bighorn sheep, caracara, zebras, African elephant, macaw, hippo, among others.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
        <a href="#cite_note-155">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Zoo Los Coyotes is a 27.68-acre (11.2 ha) zoo located south of Mexico City in the Coyoacan. It was inaugurated on February 2, 1999.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
        <a href="#cite_note-156">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It has more than 301 specimens of 51 species of wild native or endemic fauna from the Mexico City. You can admire eagles, ajolotes, coyotes, macaws, bobcats, Mexican wolves, raccoons, mountain lions, teporingos, foxes, white-tailed deer.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
        <a href="#cite_note-157">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Nicknames">
        Nicknames
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: Nicknames">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Mexico City was traditionally known as
       <i>
        La Ciudad de los Palacios
       </i>
       ("the City of the Palaces"), a nickname attributed to Baron
       <a href="/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt" title="Alexander von Humboldt">
        Alexander von Humboldt
       </a>
       when visiting the city in the 19th century, who, sending a letter back to Europe, said Mexico City could rival any major city in Europe.
      </p>
      <p>
       During
       <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Manuel_L%C3%B3pez_Obrador" title="Andrés Manuel López Obrador">
        Andrés López Obrador
       </a>
       's administration a political slogan was introduced:
       <i>
        la Ciudad de la Esperanza
       </i>
       ("The City of Hope"). This motto was quickly adopted as a city nickname, but has faded since the new motto
       <i>
        Capital en Movimiento
       </i>
       ("Capital in Movement") was adopted by the administration headed by
       <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_Ebrard" title="Marcelo Ebrard">
        Marcelo Ebrard
       </a>
       , though the latter is not treated as often as a nickname in media. Since 2013, to refer to the City particularly in relation to government campaigns, the abbreviation
       <b>
        CDMX
       </b>
       has been used (from Ciudad de México).
      </p>
      <p>
       The city is colloquially known as
       <i>
        Chilangolandia
       </i>
       after the locals' nickname
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Chilango" title="Chilango">
         chilangos
        </a>
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
        <a href="#cite_note-158">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Chilango is used pejoratively by people living outside Mexico City to "connote a loud, arrogant, ill-mannered, loutish person".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
       For their part those living in Mexico City designate insultingly those who live elsewhere as living in
       <i>
        la provincia
       </i>
       ("the provinces", the periphery) and many proudly embrace the term chilango.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
        <a href="#cite_note-160">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Residents of Mexico City are more recently called
       <i>
        defeños
       </i>
       (deriving from the postal abbreviation of the Federal District in Spanish: D.F., which is read "De-Efe"). They are formally called
       <i>
        capitalinos
       </i>
       (in reference to the city being the capital of the country), but "[p]erhaps because capitalino is the more polite, specific, and correct word, it is almost never utilized".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
        <a href="#cite_note-161">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement">
        Law enforcement
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=56" title="Edit section: Law enforcement">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_District_Police" title="Federal District Police">
        Federal District Police
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:05022012Convenio_ssp_tlalpan_mondragon_pompa070.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/05022012Convenio_ssp_tlalpan_mondragon_pompa070.JPG/220px-05022012Convenio_ssp_tlalpan_mondragon_pompa070.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/05022012Convenio_ssp_tlalpan_mondragon_pompa070.JPG/330px-05022012Convenio_ssp_tlalpan_mondragon_pompa070.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/05022012Convenio_ssp_tlalpan_mondragon_pompa070.JPG/440px-05022012Convenio_ssp_tlalpan_mondragon_pompa070.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:05022012Convenio_ssp_tlalpan_mondragon_pompa070.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Officers of the
         <a href="/wiki/Secretariat_of_Public_Security" title="Secretariat of Public Security">
          Secretariat of Public Security
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Secretariat of Public Security of the Federal District (Secretaría de Seguridad Pública del Distrito Federal – SSP) manages a combined force of over 90,000 officers in the Federal District (DF). The SSP is charged with maintaining
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_order_crime" title="Public order crime">
        public order
       </a>
       and safety in the heart of Mexico City. The historic district is also roamed by tourist police, aiming to orient and serve tourists. These horse-mounted agents dress in traditional uniforms.
      </p>
      <p>
       The investigative Judicial Police of the Federal District (Policía Judicial del Distrito Federal – PJDF) is organized under the Office of the
       <a href="/wiki/Attorney_General_of_Mexico" title="Attorney General of Mexico">
        Attorney General
       </a>
       of the DF (the Procuraduría General de Justicia del Distrito Federal). The PGJDF maintains 16 precincts (delegaciones) with an estimated 3,500 judicial police, 1,100 investigating agents for prosecuting attorneys (agentes del ministerio público), and nearly 1,000 criminology experts or specialists (peritos).
      </p>
      <p>
       Between 2000 and 2004 an average of 478 crimes were reported each day in Mexico City; however, the actual crime rate is thought to be much higher "since most people are reluctant to report crime".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
        <a href="#cite_note-162">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Under policies enacted by Mayor
       <a href="/wiki/Marcelo_Ebrard" title="Marcelo Ebrard">
        Marcelo Ebrard
       </a>
       between 2009 and 2011, Mexico City underwent a major security upgrade with violent and petty crime rates both falling significantly despite the rise in violent crime in other parts of the country. Some of the policies enacted included the installation of 11,000
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Security_camera" title="Security camera">
        security cameras
       </a>
       around the city and a very large expansion of the police force. Mexico City has one of the world's highest police officer-to-resident ratios, with one uniformed officer per 100 citizens.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
        <a href="#cite_note-163">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since 1997 the prison population has increased by more than 500%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mueller_148-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-mueller-148">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Political scientist Markus-Michael Müller argues that mostly informal street vendors are hit by these measures. He sees punishment "related to the growing politicisation of security and crime issues and the resulting criminalisation of the people living at the margins of urban society, in particular those who work in the city’s informal economy."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mueller_148-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-mueller-148">
         [148]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="International_relations">
        International relations
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=57" title="Edit section: International relations">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="399" data-file-width="512" height="39" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" width="50"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This section
          <b>
           needs additional citations for
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">

           </a>
          </b>

          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Please help

           </a>
           . Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.
          </span>
          <small>
           <i>
            (April 2015)
           </i>
          </small>
          <small class="hide-when-compact">

           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_twin_towns_and_sister_cities_in_Mexico" title="List of twin towns and sister cities in Mexico">
        List of twin towns and sister cities in Mexico
       </a>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Twin_towns_and_sister_cities">
        Twin towns and sister cities
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=58" title="Edit section: Twin towns and sister cities">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Mexico City is
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twin_towns_and_sister_cities" title="Twin towns and sister cities">
        twinned
       </a>
       with:
      </p>
      <div class="div-col columns column-count column-count-3" style="-moz-column-count: 3; -webkit-column-count: 3; column-count: 3;">
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">
           <img alt="Kazakhstan" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="600" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Flag_of_Kazakhstan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Kazakhstan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Flag_of_Kazakhstan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Kazakhstan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Flag_of_Kazakhstan.svg/46px-Flag_of_Kazakhstan.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Astana" title="Astana">
          Astana
         </a>
         , Kazakhstan
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mexico-Kazakhstan_164-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Mexico-Kazakhstan-164">
           [164]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">
           <img alt="Germany" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1000" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/35px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/46px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">
          Berlin
         </a>
         , Germany
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Berlin_twinnings_165-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Berlin_twinnings-165">
           [165]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
           <img alt="United States" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="650" data-file-width="1235" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">
          Chicago
         </a>
         , United States
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MexicoChicago_166-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-MexicoChicago-166">
           [166]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Union_of_Ibero-American_Capital_Cities">
        Union of Ibero-American Capital Cities
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico_City&amp;action=edit&amp;section=59" title="Edit section: Union of Ibero-American Capital Cities">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Mexico is part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Ibero-American_Capital_Cities" title="Union of Ibero-American Capital Cities">
        Union of Ibero-American Capital Cities
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
        <a href="#cite_note-175">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which was founded on October 12, 1982, to establish and foster brotherly relations between the following cities:
      </p>
      <div class="div-col columns column-count column-count-3" style="-moz-column-count: 3; -webkit-column-count: 3; column-count: 3;">
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <a href="/wiki/Andorra" title="Andorra">
           <img alt="Andorra" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="700" data-file-width="1000" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Flag_of_Andorra.svg/22px-Flag_of_Andorra.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Flag_of_Andorra.svg/33px-Flag_of_Andorra.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Flag_of_Andorra.svg/43px-Flag_of_Andorra.svg.png 2x" width="22"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Andorra_la_Vella" title="Andorra la Vella">
          Andorra la Vella
         </a>
         , Andorra
        </li>
        <li>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">

          </a>

         <span class="reference-text">

           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120318225631/http://tarlton.law.utexas.edu/constitutions/text/1824index.html" rel="nofollow">
            "Federal Constitution of the United Mexican States (1824)"
           </a>
           . Archived from
           <a class="external text" href="http://tarlton.law.utexas.edu/constitutions/text/1824index.html" rel="nofollow">
            the original
           </a>
           on March 18, 2012.
          </cite>

        </li>

         <span class="reference-text">

           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131022220348/http://www.redalyc.org/pdf/105/10503808.pdf" rel="nofollow">

           </a>

           .
           <i>
            Academic investigation
           </i>

           <a class="external text" href="http://www.redalyc.org/pdf/105/10503808.pdf" rel="nofollow">

        <li id="cite_note-105">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-105">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation">
           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090815115257/http://www.setravi.df.gob.mx/vialidades/transporte_vialidad.html" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             Official statistics on ground transport in Mexico City
            </i>
           </a>
           (in Spanish), SETRAVI, archived from
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.setravi.df.gob.mx/vialidades/transporte_vialidad.html" rel="nofollow">
            the original
           </a>
           on August 15, 2009
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Official+statistics+on+ground+transport+in+Mexico+City&amp;rft.pub=SETRAVI&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.setravi.df.gob.mx%2Fvialidades%2Ftransporte_vialidad.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico+City">

            </i>
           </a>
           [
           <i>
            Installation and operation of parking meters in Anzures
           </i>

            (PDF)

           (in Spanish), Miguel Hidalgo borough, Mexico City government, Autoridad del Espacio Público, archived from

           on October 22, 2013
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=INSTALACI%C3%93N+Y+OPERACI%C3%93N+DE+PARQU%C3%8DMETROS+COLONIA+ANZURES&amp;rft.pub=Miguel+Hidalgo+borough%2C+Mexico+City+government%2C+Autoridad+del+Espacio+P%C3%BAblico&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fmovil.miguelhidalgo.gob.mx%2Fuploads%2Fpresentacion_anzures.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMexico+City">

                      San Antonio
                     </a>
                    </small>
                   </li>
                  </ul>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <a href="/wiki/List_of_cathedrals_in_Uruguay" title="List of cathedrals in Uruguay">
                   Uruguay
                  </a>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <a href="/wiki/List_of_cathedrals_in_Venezuela" title="List of cathedrals in Venezuela">
                   Venezuela
                  </a>
                 </li>
                </ul>
               </div>
              </td>
             </tr>

                 <li>
                  Prehistoric Caves of
                  <a href="/wiki/Yagul" title="Yagul">
                   Yagul
                  </a>
                  and
                  <a href="/wiki/Mitla" title="Mitla">
                   Mitla
                  </a>
                  in the Central Valley of Oaxaca
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Pre-Hispanic City and National Park of
                  <a href="/wiki/Palenque" title="Palenque">
                   Palenque
                  </a>
                 </li>
                </ul>
               </div>
              </td>
             </tr>
             <tr>
              <th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">
               South Central
              </th>
              <td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
               <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
                <ul>
                 <li>
                  Archaeological Monuments Zone of
                  <a href="/wiki/Xochicalco" title="Xochicalco">
                   Xochicalco
                  </a>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <a href="/wiki/Aqueduct_of_Padre_Tembleque" title="Aqueduct of Padre Tembleque">
                   Aqueduct of Padre Tembleque
                  </a>
                  Hydraulic System
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Central University City Campus of the
                  <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Universitaria" title="Ciudad Universitaria">
                   UNAM
                  </a>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Earliest 16th-century
                  <a href="/wiki/Monasteries_on_the_slopes_of_Popocat%C3%A9petl" title="Monasteries on the slopes of Popocatépetl">
                   Monasteries on the slopes of Popocatépetl
                  </a>
                  <sup>
                   <small>
                    1
                   </small>
                  </sup>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <a href="/wiki/Camino_Real_de_Tierra_Adentro" title="Camino Real de Tierra Adentro">
                   Camino Real de Tierra Adentro
                  </a>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Historic Centres of
                  <a href="/wiki/Historic_center_of_Mexico_City" title="Historic center of Mexico City">
                   Mexico City
                  </a>
                  and
                  <a href="/wiki/Xochimilco" title="Xochimilco">
                   Xochimilco
                  </a>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <a href="/wiki/Luis_Barrag%C3%A1n_House_and_Studio" title="Luis Barragán House and Studio">
                   Luis Barragán House and Studio
                  </a>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  <a href="/wiki/Monarch_Butterfly_Biosphere_Reserve" title="Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve">
                   Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve
                  </a>
                  <sup>
                   <small>
                    1
                   </small>
                  </sup>
                 </li>
                 <li>
                  Pre-Hispanic City of
                  <a href="/wiki/Teotihuacan" title="Teotihuacan">
                   Teotihuacán
                  </a>
                 </li>
                </ul>
               </div>
              </td>
             </tr>
             <tr>
              <th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">
               South East
              </th>
              <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">

                  </a>
                  , Campeche
                 </li>

                  </a>
                 </li>

                  </a>
                 </li>

                  </a>
                 </li>

                  <a href="/wiki/Uxmal" title="Uxmal">

                  </a>
                 </li>

              </td>
             </tr>
            </table>
           </div>
           <div aria-labelledby="World&amp;#039;s_fifty_most-populous_urban_areas" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px">
            <table class="nowraplinks collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit">
             <tr>
              <th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col">
               <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
                <ul>
                 <li class="nv-view">
                  <a href="/wiki/Template:World%27s_most_populous_urban_areas" title="Template:World's most populous urban areas">
                   <abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none;" title="View this template">
                    v
                   </abbr>
                  </a>
                 </li>
                 <li class="nv-talk">
                  <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:World%27s_most_populous_urban_areas" title="Template talk:World's most populous urban areas">

                    t
                   </abbr>
                  </a>
                 </li>
                 <li class="nv-edit">
                  <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:World%27s_most_populous_urban_areas&amp;action=edit">
                   <abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none;" title="Edit this template">
                    e
                   </abbr>
                  </a>
                 </li>
                </ul>
               </div>
               <div id="World&amp;#039;s_fifty_most-populous_urban_areas" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em">
                World's fifty
